div.head: ACTVS PRIMVS.
div.stage: Enter Luke Greene-shield with Fetherstone booted.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: ARt sure old Maybery Innes here to night,

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Tis certaine the honest knaue Chamberleine that hath bin my Informer, my baud, euer since I knew Ware assures me of it, and more being a Londoner though altogether vnacquainted, I haue requested his company at supper.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Excellent occasion: how wee shall carry our selues in this busines is onely to be thought vpon.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Be that my vndertaking: if I do not take a full reuenge of his wiues puritanicall coynesse.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Suppose it she should be chast,

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: O hang her: this art of seeming honest makes many of our young sonnes and heires in the Citty, looke so like our prentises,â Chamberlaine.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Heare Sir. Enter Chamberlaine.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: This honest knaue is call'd Innocence, ist not a good name for a Chamberlaine? he dwelt at Dunstable not long since, and hath brought me and the two Butchers Daughters there to interuiew twenty times & not so little I protest: how chance you left dunstable Sirra?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Faith Sir the towne droopt euer since the peace in Ireland, your captaines were wont to take their leaues of their London Polecats, (their wenches I meane Sir) at Dunstable: the next morning when they had broke their fast togeather the wenches brought them to quickly 'ith hole, & so the one for London the other for Westchester, your onely rode now Sir is Yorke Yorke Sir.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: True, but yet it comes scant of the Prophesy; Lincolne was, London is, and Yorke shall-be.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Yes Sir, tis fullfild, Yorke shalbe, that is, it shalbe Yorke still, surely it was the meaning of the prophet: will you haue some Cray-fish, and a Spitchcocke.

div.stage: Enter Maybery with Bellamont.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: And a fat Trout.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: You shall Sir; the Londoners you wot of:

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Most kindly welcomeâ I beseech you hold our bouldnesse excused Sir.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Sir it is the health of Trauailers, to inioy good company: will you walke.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Whether Trauaile you I beseech you.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: To London Sir we came from Sturbridge.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I tel you Gentlemen I haue obseru'd very much with being at sturbridge; it hath afforded me mirth beyond the length of fiue lattin Comedies; here should you meete a Nor-folk yeoman ful-but; with his head able to ouer-turne you; and his pretty wife that followed him, ready to excuse the ignorant hardnesse of her husbands forhead, in the goose markt number of freshmen; stuck here and there, with a graduate: like cloues with great heads in a gammon of bacon: here two gentlemen making a mariage betweene their heires ouer a wool-pack; there a Ministers wife that could speake false lattine very lispingly; here two in one corner of a shop: Londoners selling their wares, & other Gentlemen courting their wiues; where they take vp petticoates you shold finde schollers & towns-mens wiues crouding togither while their husbands weare in another market busie amongst the Oxen; twas like a campe for in other Countries so many Punks do not follow an army. I could make an excellent discription of it in a Comedy: but whether are you trauailyng Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Feth
sp.p: Faith Sir we purposed a dangerous voiage, but vpon better consideration we alterd our course.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: May we without offence pertake the ground of it.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Tis altogither triuial in-sooth: but to passe away the time till supper, Ile deliuer it to you, with protestation before hand, I seeke not to publish euery gentle-womans dishonor, only by the passage of my discource to haue you censure the state of our quarrel.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Forth Sir.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Frequenting the company of many marchants wiues in the Citty, my heart by chance leapt into mine eye to affect the fairest but with al the falsest creature that euer affection stoopt to.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Of what ranck was she I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Vpon your promise of secresie.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You shall close it vp like treasure of your owne, and your selfe shall keepe the key of it,

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: She was and by report still is wife to a most graue and well reputed Cittizen.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: And entertaind your loue.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: As Meddowes do Aprill: the violence as it seemed of her affectionâ but alas it proued her dissembling, would at my comming and departing be-dew her eyes with loue dropps; O she could the art of woman most feelingly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Most feelingly.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I should not haue lik'd that feelingly had she beene my wife, giue vs some sack heare and in faithâ we are all friends; & in priuateâ what was her husbands name.â Ile giue you a carouse by and by.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: O you shall pardon mee his name, it seemes you are a Cittizen, it would bee discourse inough for you vpon the exchange this fort-night should I tell his name.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your modesty in this wiues commendation; on sir.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: In the passage of our loues, (amongst other fauours of greater valew) she bestowed vpon me this ringe which she protested was her husbands gift.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: The poesie, the poesieâ O my heart, that ring good infaith:

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Not many nights comming to her and being familiar with her.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Kissing and so forth.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And talking to her feelingly.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Pox on't, I lay with her.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Good infaith you are of a good complexion.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Lying with her as I say: and rising some-what early from her in the morning, I lost this ring in her bed.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: In my wiues bed.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: How do you Sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Nothing: lettes haue a fire chamberlaine; I thinke my bootes haue taken water I haue such a shudering: ith' bed you say;

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Right Sir, in Mistris Maiberies sheetes.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Was her name Maybery.

sp.speaker: Green
sp.p: Beshrew my tongue for blabbing, I presume vpon your secresy.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O God Sir, but where did you find your loosing;

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Where I found her falsnesse: with this Gentleman; who by his owne confession pertaking the like inioyment; found this ring the same morning on her pillowe, and sham'd not in my sight to weare it.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
What did shee talke feelingly to him too; I warrant her husband was forth a Towne all this while,
and he poore man trauaild with hard Egges in's pocket, to saue the charge of a baite, whilst she was at home with her Plouers, Turkey, Chickens; do you know that Maibery.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: No more then by name.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Hee's a wondrous honest man; lets be merry; will not your mistrisse gentlemen, you are tenants in common I take it.

sp.speaker: Feth Gree.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Will not your Mistresse make much of her husband when he comes home as if no such legerdemaine had bin acted.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Yes she hath reason for't, for in some countries, where men and women haue good trauailing stomackes, they begin with porredge; then they fall to Capon or so-forth: but if Capon come short of filling their bellies, to their porridge againe, tis their onely course, so for our women in England.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: This wit taking of long iourneys: kindred that comes in ore the hatch, and sailing to Westminster makes a number of Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fie what an idle quarrell is this, was this her ring?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Her ring Sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: A pretty idle toy, would you would take mony for't,

sp.speaker: Feth. Green.
sp.p: Mony sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: The more I looke on't, the more I like it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Troth 'tis of no great valew, and considering the losse, and finding of this ring made breach into your friendship, Gentlemen, with this trifle purchase his loue, I can tell you he keepes a good Table.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: What my Mistris gift?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Faith you are a merry old Gentleman; Ile giue you my part in't.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Troth and mine, with your promise to conceale it from her husband.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Doth he know of it yet?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: He shall neuer then I protest: looke you this ring doth fitte me passing well.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: I am glad we haue fitted you.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: This walking is wholesome, I was a cold euen now, now I sweat for't.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Shalls walke into the Garden Luke. Gentlemen weele downe and hasten supper.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Looke you, we must be better acquainted that's all.

div.stage: Exeunt Green. and Feth.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Most willingly; Excellent, hee's heat to the proofe, lets with-draw, and giue him leaue to raue a little.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Chamberlaine, giue vs a cleane Towell.

div.stage: Enter Chamberlaine.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How now man?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I am foolish old Maybery, and yet I can be wise Maybery too; Ile to London presently, begon Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How, how?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Gods pretious you doe mistake mee Maister Bellamont; I am not distempered, for to know a mans wife is a whore, is to be resolu'd of it, and to be resolued of it, is to make no question of it, and when a case is out of question; what was I saying?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why looke you, what a distraction are you falne into?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: If a man be deuorst, doe you see, deuorst forma Iuris, whether may he haue an action or no, gainst those that make hornes at him?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O madnesse! that the frailty of a woman should make a wise man thus idle! yet I protest to my vnderstanding, this report seemes as farre from truth, as you from patience.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Then am I a foole, yet I can bee wise and I list too: what sayes my wedding ring?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Indeed that breeds some suspition: for the rest most grose and open, for two men, both to loue your wife, both to inioy her bed, and to meete you as if by miracle, and not knowing you, vpon no occasion in the world, to thrust vpon you a discourse of a quarrell, with circumstance so dishonest, that not any Gentleman but of the countrie blushing, would haue publisht. I and to name you: doe you know them?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Faith now I remember, I haue seene them walke muffled by my shop.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Like enough; pray God they doe not borrow mony of vs twixt Ware and London: come striue to blow ouer these clowdes.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Not a clowd, you shall haue cleane Moone-shine, they haue good smooth lookes the fellowes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As Iet, they will take vp I warrant you, where they may bee trusted; will you be merry?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Wonderous merry; lets haue some Sack to drowne this Cuckold, downe with him: wonderous merry: one word & no more; I am but a foolish tradesman, and yet Ile be a wise tradesman. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Doll lead betweene Leuer-poole, and Chartley, after them Philip arrested.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Arrest me? at whose sute? Tom Chartley, Dick Leuer-poole, stay, Ime arrested.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Arrested?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Gentlemen breake not the head of the peace; its to no purpose, for hee's in the lawes clutches, you see hee's fangd.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Vds life, doe you stand with your naked weapons in your hand, and doe nothing with em? put one of em into my fingers, Ile tickle the pimple-nosed varlets.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hold Doll, thrust not a weapon vpon a mad woman, Officers step back into the Tauerne, you might ha tane mee ith streete, and not ith' Tauerne entrie, you Cannibals.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Wee did it for your credit Sir.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: How much is the debt? Drawer, some wine.

div.stage: Enter Drawer.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Foure score pound: can you send for Baile Sir? or what will you doe? wee cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: You cannot, you pasty-footed Rascalls, you will stay one day in hell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Foure score pounds drawes deepe; farewell Doll, come Serieants, Ile step to mine Vncle not farre off, here-by in Pudding lane, and he shall baile mee: if not, Chartly you shall finde me playing at Span-counter, and so farewell. Send mee some Tobacco.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Haue an eye to his hands.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Haue an eye to his legges. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Ime as melancholy now?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Villanous spitefull luck, Ile hold my life some of these sawsie Drawers betrayd him.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Wee sir! no by Gad Sir, wee scorne to haue a Iudas in our company.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: No, no, hee was dogd in, this is the end of all dyeing.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: This is the end of all whores, to fall into the hands of knaues. Drawer, tye my shoe pry thee: the new knot as thou seest this: Philip is a good honest Gentleman, I loue him because heele spend, but when I saw him on his Fathers Hobby, and a brace of Punkes following him in a coach, I told him hee would run out, hast done boy?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Yes forsooth: by my troth you haue a dainty legge.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: How now good-man rogue.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Nay sweete Mistresse Doll.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Doll! you reprobate! out you Bawd for seauen yeares by the custome of the Citty.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Good Mistris Dorothy; the pox take mee, if I toucht your legge but to a good intent.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Prate you: the rotten toothd rascall, will for sixe pence fetch any whore to his maisters customers: and is euery one that swims in a Taffatie gowne Lettis for your lippes? vds life, this is rare, that Gentlewomen and Drawers, must suck at one Spiggot: Doe you laugh you vnseasonable puck-fist? doe you grin?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Away Drawer: hold pry thee good rogue, holde my sweete Doll, a pox a this swaggering.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Pox a your gutts, your kidneys; mew: hang yee, rooke: I'me as melancholy now as Fleet-streete in a long vacation.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Melancholy? come weele ha some muld Sack.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: When begins the terme?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Why? hast any suites to be tryed at Westminster?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: My Sutes you base ruffian haue beene tryed at Westminster already: so soone as euer the terme begins, Ile change my lodging, it stands out a the way; Ile lye about Charing-crosse, for if there be any stirrings, there we shall haue 'em: or if some Dutch-man would come from the States! oh! these Flemmings pay soundly for what they take.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: If thou't haue a lodging West-ward Doll, Ile fitte thee.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p:
At Tyburne will you not? a lodging of your prouiding? to bee cal'd a Lieutenants, or a Captaines wench! oh! I scorne to bee one of your Low-country commodities, I; is this body made to bee mainteined with Prouant and dead
pay? no: the Mercer must bee paide, and Sattin gownes must bee tane vp.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: And gallon pots must be tumbled downe.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Stay: I haue had a plot a breeding in my brainesâ Are all the Quest-houses broken vp?

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Yes, long since: what then?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: What then? mary then is the wind come about, and for those poore wenches that before Christmasse fled West-ward with bag and baggage, come now sailing alongst the lee shore with a Northerly winde, and we that had warrants to lie without the liberties, come now dropping into the freedome by Owle-light sneakingly.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But Doll, whats the plot thou spakst off?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Mary this: Gentlemen, and Tobacco-stinckers, and such like are still buzzing where sweete meates are (like Flyes) but they make any flesh stinke that they blow vpon: I will leaue those fellowes therefore in the hands of their Landresses: Siluer is the Kings stampe, man Gods stampe, and a woman is mans stampe, wee are not currant till wee passe from one man to another.

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: I will therefore take a faire house in the Citty: no matter tho it be a Tauerne that has blowne vp his Maister: it shall be in trade still, for I know diuerse Tauernes ith Towne, that haue but a Wall betweene them and a hotte-house. It shall then bee giuen out, that I'me a Gentlewoman of such a birth, such a wealth, haue had such a breeding, and so foorth, and of such a carriage, and such quallities, and so forth: to set it off the better, old Iack Hornet shall take vppon him to bee my Father.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Excellent, with a chaine about his neck and so forth.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: For that, Saint Martins and wee will talke: I know we shall haue Gudgions bite presently: if they doe boyes, you shall liue like Knights fellowes; as occasion serues, you shall weare liueries and waite, but when Gulls are my winde-falls, you shall be Gentlemen, and keepe them company: seeke out Iack Hornet incontinently.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Wee will; come Charely, weele playe our partes I warrant.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Doe so:â
The world's a stage, from which strange shapes we borrow:
To day we are honest, and ranke knaues to morrow. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Maybery, Bellamont, and a Prentice.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Where is your Mistris, villaine? when went she abroad?

sp.speaker: Prent.
sp.p: Abroad Sir, why assoone as she was vp Sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Vp Sir, downe Sir, so sir: Maister Bellamont, I will tell you a strange secret in Nature, this boy is my wiues bawd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O fie sir, fie, the boy he doe's not looke like a Bawde, he has no double chin.

sp.speaker: Pren.
sp.p: No sir, nor my breath does not stinke, I smell not of Garlick or Aqua-vitae: I vse not to bee drunke with Sack and Sugar: I sweare not God dam me, if I know where the party is, when 'tis a lye and I doe know: I was neuer Carted (but in haruest) neuer whipt but at Schoole: neuer had the Grincoms: neuer sold one Maiden-head ten seuerall times, first to an Englishman, then to a Welshman, then to a Dutchman, then to a pockie Frenchman, I hope Sir I am no Bawd then.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Thou art a Baboune, and holdst me with trickes, whilst my Wife grafts grafts, away, trudge, run, search her out by land, and by water.

sp.speaker: Pren.
sp.p: Well Sir, the land Ile ferret, and after that Ile search her by water, for it may be shees gone to Brainford. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mayb.
sp.p: Inquire at one of mine Aunts.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: One of your Aunts are you mad?

sp.speaker: Mayb.
sp.p: Yea, as many of the twelue companies are, troubled, troubled.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ile chide you: goe too, Ile chide you soundly.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Oh maister Bellamont!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh Maister Maybery! before your Seruant to daunce a Lancashire Horne-pipe: it shewes worse to mee, then dancing does to a deafe man that sees not the fiddles: Sfoot you talke like a Player.

sp.speaker: Mayb.
sp.p: If a Player talke like a mad-man, or a foole, or an Asse, and knowes not what hee talkes, then Ime one: you are a Poet Maister Bellamont, I will bestow a piece of Plate vpon you to bring my wife vpon the Stage, wud not her humor please Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I thinke it would: yours wud make Gentlemen as fatt as fooles: I wud giue two peeces of Plate, to haue you stand by me, when I were to write a iealous mans part: Iealous men are eyther knaues or Coxcombes, bee you neither: you weare yellow hose without cause.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: With-out cause, when my Mare beares double: without cause?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And without wit.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: When two Virginall Iacks skip vp, as the key of my instrument goes downe!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: They are two wicked elders.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: When my wiues ring does smoake for't.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your wiues ring may deceiue you.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O Maister Bellamont! had it not beene my wife had made me a Cuckold, it should neuer haue greeued mee.

sp.speaker: Bel,
sp.p: You wrong her vpon my soule.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: No, she wrongs me vpon her body.

div.stage: Enter a Seruingman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Now blew-bottle? what flutter you for Sea-pye?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Not to catch fish Sir, my young Maister, your sonne maister Philip is taken prisoner.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: By the Dunkirks.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Worse: by Catch-polls: hee's encountred.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Shall I neuer see that prodigall come home.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Sir, if youle fetch him out, you may kill a Calfe for him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: For how much lyes he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The debt is foure score pound, marry he chargde mee to tell you it was foure score and ten, so that he lies onely for the odde ten pound.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: His childs part shal now be paid, this mony shalbe his last, & this vexation the last of mine: if you had such a sonne maister Maiberie.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: To such a wife, twere an excellent couple.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Release him, and release me of much sorrow, I will buy a Sonne no more: goe redeeme him. Enter Prentice and Maiberies wife.

sp.speaker: Prent.
sp.p: Here's the party Sir.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: Hence, and lock fast the dores, now is my prize.

sp.speaker: Prent.
sp.p: If she beate you not at your owne weapon, wud her Buckler were cleft in two peeces. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I will not haue you handle her too roughly.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: No, I will like a Iustice of peace, grow to the point: are not you a whore: neuer start: thou art a Cloth-worker, and hast turnd me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: How Sir, into what Sir, haue I turn'd you?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Into a Ciuill Suite: into a sober beast: a Land-rat, a Cuckold: thou art a common bedfellow, art not? art not?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Sir this Language, to me is strange, I vnderstand it not.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O! you studie the french now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Good Sir, lend me patience.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I made a sallade of that herbe: doest see these flesh-hookes, I could teare out those false eyes, those Cats eyes, that can see in the night: punck I could.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Heare her answer for her selfe.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Good Maister Bellomont,
Let him not do me violence: deere Sir,
Should any but your selfe shoote out these names,
I would put off all female modesty,
To be reueng'd on him.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Know'st thou this ring? there has bin old running at the ring since I went.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Yes Sir, this ring is mine, he was a villayne,
That stole it from my hand: he was a villayne:
That put it into yours.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.l: They were no villaynes,
When they stood stoutly for me: tooke your part:
And stead of collours fought vnder my sheetes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I know not what you meane.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: They lay with the: I meane plaine dealing.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: With me! if euer I had thought vncleane,
In detestation of your nuptiall pillow:
Let Sulpher drop from Heauen, and naile my body
Dead to this earth: that slaue, that damned fury
(Whose whips are in your tongue to torture me)
Casting an eye vnlawfull on my cheeke,
Haunted your thre-shold daily, and threw forth
All tempting baytes which lust and credulous youth,
Apply to our fraile sex: but those being weake
The second seige he layd was in sweete wordes.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: And then the breach was made.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay, nay, heare all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: At last he takes me sitting at your dore,
Seizes my palme, and by the charme of othes
(Back to restore it straight) he won my hand,
To crowne his finger with that hoope of gold.
I did demand it, but he mad with rage
And with desires vnbrideled, fled and vow'd,
That ring should mee vndo: and now belike
His spells haue wrought on you. But I beseech you,
To dare him to my face, and in meane time
Deny me bed-roome, driue me from your board,
Disgrace me in the habit of your slaue,
Lodge me in some discomfortable vault
Where neither Sun nor Moone may touch my sight,
Till of this slander I my soule acquite.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Guiltlesse vpon my soule.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.l: Troth so thinke I.
I now draw in your bow, as I before
Suppos'd they drew in mine: my streame of ielozy,
Ebs back againe, and I that like a horse
Ran blind-fold in a Mill (all in one circle)
Yet thought I had gon fore-right, now spy my error:
Villaines you haue abus'd me, and I vow
Sharp vengeance on your heads: driue in your teares
I take your word ya're honest, which good men,
Very good men will scarce do to their wiues.
I will bring home these serpents and allow them,
The heate of mine owne bosome: wife I charge you
Set out your hauiours towards them in such collours,
As if you had bin their whore, Ile haue it so,
Ile candy o're my words, and sleeke my brow,
Intreate 'em that they would not point at me,
Nor mock my hornes, with this Arme Ile embrace 'em
And with thisâ go too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh we shall haue murderâ you kill my heart.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.l: No: I will shed no bloud,
But I will be reueng'd, they that do wrong
Teach others way to right: Ile fetch my blow
Faire and a far off and as Fencers vse Enter Philip and seruant
Tho at the foote I strike, the head Ile bruize.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ile ioyne with you: lets walke: oh! heres my Sonne.
Welcome a shore Sir: from whence come you pray.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: From the house of praier and fastingâ the Counter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Art not, thou asham'd to bee seene come out of a prison.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: No Gods my Iudge, but I was asham'd to goe into prison.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I am told sir, that you spend your credit and your coine vpon a light woman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I ha seene light gold sir, passe away amongst Mercers.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And that you haue layd thirty or fortie pounds vpon her back in taffaty gownes, and silke petticoates.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: None but Taylors will say so, I nere lay'd any thing vpon her backe: I confesse I tooke vp a petticoate and a raiz'd fore-part for her, but who has to do with that?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Mary that has euery body Maister Philip.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Leaue her company, or leaue me, for shee's a woman of an ill name.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Her name is Dorothy sir, I hope thats no il name.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What is she? what wilt thou do with her?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sbloud sir what does he with her?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Doest meane to marry her? of what birth is shee? what are her commings in, what does she liue vpon?

sp.speaker: Phillip.
sp.p: Rents sir, Rents, shee liues vpon her Rents, and I can haue her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You can.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay father, if destiny dogge mee I must haue her: you haue often tould mee the nine Muses are all women, and you deale with them, may not I the better bee allowed one than you so many? looke you Sir, the Northerne man loues white-meates, the Southery man Sallades, the Essex man a Calfe, the Kentishman a Wag-taile, the Lancashire man an Egg-pie, the Welshman Leekes and Cheese, and your Londoners rawe Mutton, so Father god-boy, I was borne in London.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p:
Stay, looke you Sir, as hee that liues vpon Sallades without Mutton, feedes like an Oxe, (for hee eates
grasse you knowe) yet rizes as hungry as an Asse, and as hee that makes a dinner of leekes will haue leane cheekes, so, thou foolish Londoner, if nothing but raw mutton can diet thee, looke to liue like a foole and a slaue, and to die like a begger and a knaue, come Maister Maiberie, farewell boy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Farewell father Snotâ Sir if I haue her, Ile spend more in mustard & vineger in a yeare, then both you in beefe.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: More saucy knaue thou. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus 2. Scena. 1.
div.stage: Enter Hornet, Doll, Leuerpoole and Chartly like seruingmen.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: AM I like a fidlers base violl (new set vp,) in a good case boies? ist neate, is it terse! am I hansome? ha!

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Admirable, excellent.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: An vnder sheriffe cannot couer a knaue more cunningly.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Sfoot if he should come before a Church-warden, he wud make him peu-fellow with a Lords steward at least.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: If I had but a staffe in my hand, fooles wud thinke I were one of Simon and Iudes gentlemen vshers, and that my apparell were hir'd: they say three Taylors go to the making vp of a man, but Ime sure I had foure Taylors and a halfe went to the making of me thus: this Suite tho it ha bin canuast well, yet tis no law-suite, for twas dispatcht sooner than a posset on a wedding night.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Why I tel thee Iack Hornet, if the Diuel and all the Brokers in long lane had rifled their wardrob, they wud ha beene dambd before they had fitted thee thus.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Punck, I shall bee a simple father for you: how does my chaine show now I walke.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: If thou wert hung in chaines, thou couldst not show better.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But how fit our blew-coates on our backes.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: As they do vpon banckrout retainers backes at Saint Georges feast in London: but at Westminster, It makes 'em scorne the badge of their occupation: there the bragging velure-caniond hobbi-horses, praunce vp and downe as if some a the Tilters had ridden 'em.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Nay Sfoot, if they be banckrouts, tis like some haue ridden
'em: and there-vpon the Cittizens Prouerbe rises, when hee sayes; he trusts to a broken staffe.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Hornet, now you play my Father, take heed you be not out of your part, and shame your adopted Daughter.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: I will looke grauely Doll, (doe you see boyes) like the fore-man of a Iury: and speake wisely like a Lattin Schoolemaister, and be surly and dogged, and proud like the Keeper of a prison.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: You must lie horribly, when you talke of your lands.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: No shop-keeper shall out lye mee, nay, no Fencer: when I hem boyes, you shall duck: when I cough and spit gobbets Doll.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: The pox shall be in your lungs Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: No Doll, these with their high shoes shall tread me out.

sp.speaker: Doll,
sp.p: All the lessons that I ha prickt out for 'em, is when the Wether-cock of my body turnes towards them, to stand bare.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: And not to be sawcie as Seruing-men are.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Come, come, we are no such creatures as you take vs for.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: If we haue but good draughts in my peeter-boate, fresh Salmon you sweete villaines shall be no meate with vs.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Sfoot nothing mooues my choller, but that my chaine is Copper: but tis no matter, better men than old Iack Hornet haue rode vp Holburne, with as bad a thing about their neckes as this: your right whiffler indeed hangs himselfe in Saint Martins, and not in Cheape-side.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Peace, some-body rings: run both, whilst he has the the rope in's hand if it be a prize, hale him, if a man a war, blow him vp, or hang him out at the maine yeards end.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: But what ghost, (hold vp my fine Girle) what ghosts haunts thy house?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Oh! why diuerse: I haue a Clothiers Factor or two; a Grocer that would faine Pepper me, a Welsh Captaine that laies hard seege, a Dutch Marchant, that would spend al that he's able to make ith' low countries, but to take measure of my Holland sheetes when I lye in 'em: I heare trampling: 'tis my Flemish Hoy.

div.stage: Enter Leuerpoole, Chartly and Hans van Belch.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p:
Dar is vor you, and vor you: een, twea, drie, vier, and
viue skilling, drinks Skellum vysie frÃ©ese: nempt, dats v drinck gelt.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Till our crownes crack agen Maister Hans van Belch.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: How ist met you, how ist bro? brolick?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Ick vare well God danke you: Nay Ime an apt scholler and can take.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Datt is good, dott is good: Ick can nÃ©et stay long: for Ick heben skip come now vpon de vater: O mine schoomen vro, wee sall dance lanteera, teera, and sing Ick brincks to you min here, van:â wat man is dat vro.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Nay pray sir on.

sp.speaker: Hans
sp.p: Wat honds foot is dat Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Tis my father.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Gotts Sacrament! your vader! why seyghen you niet so to me! mine heart tis mine all great desire, to call you mine vader ta for Ick loue dis schonen vro your dochterkin.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Sir you are welcome in the way of honesty.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Ick bedanck you: Ick heb so ghe founden vader.

sp.speaker: Harn.
sp.p: Whats your name I pray.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Mun nom bin Hans van Belch.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Hans Van Belch!

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yau, yau, tis so, tis so, de dronken man is alteet remenber me.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Doe you play the marchant, sonne Belch.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yau vader: Ick heb de skip swim now vpon de vater if you endouty, goe vp in de little Skip dat goe so, and bÃ©e puld vp to Wapping, Ick sal beare you on my backe, and hang you about min neck into min groet Skip.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: He Sayes Doll, he would haue thee to Wapping and hang thee.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: No Father I vnderstand him, but maister Hans, I would not be seene hanging about any mans neck, to be counted his Iewell, for any gold.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Is your father liuing Maister Hans.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yau, yau, min vader heb schonen husen in Ausburgh groet mine heare is mine vaders broder, mine vader heb land, and bin full of see, dat is beasts, cattell

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He's lowzy be-like.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Min vader bin be grotest fooker in all Ausbrough.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: The greatest what?

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Fooker he saies.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Out vpon him.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Yaw yaw, fooker is en groet min here hees en elderman vane Citty, gots sacrament, wat is de clock? Ick met stay. A watch.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Call his watch before you, if you can.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Her's a pretty thing: do these wheeles spin vp the houres! what's a clock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Acht: yaw tis acht.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: We can heare neither clock, nor Iack going, wee dwell in such a place that I feare I shall neuer finde the way to Church, because the bells hang so farre; Such a watch as this, would make me go downe with the Lamb, and be vp with the Larke.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Seghen you so, dor it to.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: O fie: I doe but iest, for in trueth I could neuer abide a watch.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Gotts sacrament, Ick niet heb it any more.

div.stage: Exeunt Leuer-poole and Chartly.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: An other peale! good father lanch out this hollander.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Come Maister Belch, I will bring you to the water-side, perhaps to Wapping, and there ile leaue you.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Ick bedanck you vader. Exit.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: They say Whores and bawdes go by clocks, but what a Manasses is this to buy twelue houres so deerely, and then bee begd out of'em so easily? heele be out at heeles shortly sure for he's out about the clockes already: O foolish young man how doest thou spend thy time?

div.stage: Enter Leuer-poole first, then Allom and Chartly.

sp.speaker: Leur.
sp.p: Your grocer.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Nay Sfoot, then ile change my tune: I may cause such leaden-heeld rascalls; out of my sight: a knife, a knife I say: O Maister Allom, if you loue a woman, draw out your knife and vndo me, vndo me.

sp.speaker: Allo.
sp.p: Sweete mistris Dorothy, what should you do with a knife, its ill medling with edge tooles, what's the matter Maisters! knife God blesse vs.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Sfoot what tricks at noddy are these.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Oh I shal burst, if I cut not my lace: I'me so vext! my father hee's ridde to Court: one was about a matter of a 1000. pound weight; and one of his men like a roague as he is is rid another way for rents, I lookt to haue had him vp yesterday, and vp to day, and yet hee showes not his head; sure he's run away, or robd & run thorough; and here was a scriuener but euen now, to put my father in minde of a bond, that wilbe forfit this night if the mony be not payd Maister Allom. Such crosse fortune!

sp.speaker: Allo.
sp.p: How much is the bond?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: O rare little villaine.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: My father could take vp, vpon the barenesse of his word fiue hundred pound: and fiue toe.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: What is the debt?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: But hee scornes to beeâ and I scorne to beeâ

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Pree thee sweete Mistris Dorothy vex not, how much is it?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Alas Maister Allom, tis but poore fifty pound.

sp.speaker: Allo.
sp.p: If that bee all, you shall vpon your worde take vp so much with me: another time Ile run as far in your bookes.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Sir, I know not how to repay this kindnesse: but when my fatherâ

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Tush, tush, tis not worth the talking: Iust 50 pound? when is it to be payd.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Betweene one and two.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: That's wee thre.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Let one of your men goe along, and Ile send your fifty pound!

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: You so bind mee sir,â goe sirra: Maister Allom, I ha some quinces brought from our house ith Country to preserue, when shall we haue any good Suger come ouer? the warres in Barbary make Suger at such an excessiue rate; you pay sweetely now I warrant, sir do you not.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.p: You shal haue a whole chest of Sugar if you please.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Nay by my faith foure or fiue loues wil-be enough, and Ile pay you at my first child Maister Allom.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Content ifaith, your man shall bring all vnder one, ile borrow a kisse of you at parting.

div.stage: Enter Captaine Iynkins.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: You shall sir, I borrow more of you. Ex. Allo. & Leu.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Saue you Captaine.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Welcome good captaine Iynkins.

sp.speaker: Captaine.
sp.p: What is hee a Barber Surgeon, that drest your lippes so.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: A Barber! hee's may Taylor; I bidde him measure how hie, hee would make the standing coller of my new Taffatie Gowne before, and hee as Tailors wilbe sawcie and lickerish, laid mee ore the lippes.

sp.speaker: Captaine.
sp.p: Vds bloud ile laie him crosse vpon his coxcomb next daie.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: You know tis not for a Gentlewoman to stand with a knaue, for a small matter, and so I wud not striue with him, onelie to be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If I take Maister prick-louse ramping so hie againe, by this Iron (which is none a gods Angell) ile make him know how to kisse your blind cheekes sooner: mistris Dorothy Hornet, I wud not haue you bee a hornet, to licke at Cowsherds, but to sting such shreds of rascallity: will you sing a Tailor shall haue mee my ioy?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Captaine, ile bee lead by you in any thing! a Taylor! foh.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Of what stature or sise haue you a stomach to haue your husband now?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Of the meanest stature Captaine, not a size longer than your selfe, nor shorter.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By god, tis wel said: all your best Captaine in the Low-countries are as taller as I: but why of my pitch Mistris Dol?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Because your smallest Arrowes flie farthest; ah you little hard-fauord villaine, but sweete villaine, I loue thee beecause thou't draw a my side, hang the roague that will not fight for a woman.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Vds blould, and hange him for vrse than a roague that will slash and cut for an oman, if she be a whore.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Pree thee good Captaine Iynkins, teach mee to speake some welch, mee thinkes a Welchmans tongue is the neatest tongue!â

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: As any tongue in the vrld, vnlesse Cramacrees, that's vrse.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: How do you say, I loue you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Mi cara whee, en hellon.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Mi cara whee, en hel-hound.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hel-hound, o mondu, my cara whee, en hellon.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: O, my cara whee en hellon.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Oh! and you went to wryting schoole twenty score yeare in Wales, by Sesu, you cannot haue better vttrance, for welch.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Come tit mee, come tat mee, come throw a kisse at me, how is that?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By gad I kanow not, what your tit mees and tat mees are, but mee uathaâ Sbloud I know what kisses be, aswel as I know a Welch hooke, if you will goe downe with Shrop-sheere cariers, you shal haue Welch enough in your pellies forty weekes.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Say Captaine that I should follow your collours into your Country how should I fare there?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Fare? by Sesu, O there is the most abominable seere! and wider siluer pots to drinck in, and softer peds to lie vpon & do our necessary pusines, and fairer houses and parkes, & holes for Conies, and more money, besides tosted Sees and buttermilke in Northwales diggon: besides, harpes, & Welch Freeze, and Goates, and Cow-heeles, and Metheglin, ouh, it may be set in the Kernicles, wil you march thither?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Not with your Shrop-sheire cariers, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Will you go with Captaine Ienkin and see his Couzen Maddoc vpon Ienkin there, and ile run hedlongs by and by, & batter away money for a new Coach to iolt you in.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Bestow your Coach vpon me, & two young white Mares, and you shall see how Ile ride.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Will you? by all the leekes that are worne on Saint Dauies daie I will buy not only a Coach, with foure wheeles, but also a white Mare and a stone horse too, because they shal traw you, very lustily, as if the diuill were in their arses. Exit .How now, more Tailorsâ Meetes Phillip.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How sir; Taylors.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: O good Captaine, tis my Couzen.

div.stage: Enter Leuerpoole at another dore.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Is he, I will Couzen you then sir too, one day.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I hope sir then to Couzen you too.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By gad I hobe so, fare-well Sidanien. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Her's both money, and suger.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: O sweete villaine, set it vp. Exit, and Enter presently.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sfoot, what tame suaggerer was this I met Doll.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: A Captaine, a Captaine: but hast scap't the Dunkirks honest Philip? Philip ryalls are not more welcome: did thy father pay the shot?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He pai'd that shot, and then shot pistolets into my pockets: harke wench: chinck chink, makes the punck wanton and the Baud to winck. Capers.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: O rare musick.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Heauenly consort, better than old Moones.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But why? why Dol, goe these two like Beadells in blew? ha?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Theres a morrall in that: flea off your skins, you pretious Caniballs: O that the welch Captaine were here againe, and a drum with him, I could march now, ran, tan, tan, tara, ran, tan, tan, sirra Philip has thy father any plate in's house.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Enough to set vp a Gold-smithes shop.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Canst not borrow some of it? wee shall haue guests to morrow or next day and I wud serue the hungry rag-a-muffins in plate, tho twere none of mine owne.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I shall hardly borrow it of him but I could get one of mine Aunts, to beate the bush for mee, and she might get the bird.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Why pree, let me bee one of thine Aunts, and doe it for me then. As Ime vertuous and a Gentlewoman ile restore.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Say no more tis don.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: What manner of man is thy father? Sfoot ide faine see the witty Monky because thou sayst he's a Poet: ile tell thee, what ile do: Leuer-poole or Chartly, shall like my Gentleman vsher goe to him, and say such a Lady sends for him, about a sonnet or an epitaph for her child that died at nurse, or for some deuice about a maske or so; if he comes you shall stand in a corner, and see in what State ile beare my selfe: he does not know me, nor my lodging.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Ist a match Sirs? shalls be mery with him and his muse.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Agreed, any scaffold to execute knauery vpon.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Ile send then my vant-currer presently: in the meane time, marche after the Captaine, scoundrels, come hold me vp:

lg.l: Looke how Sabrina sunck ith' riuer Seuerne,
So will we foure be drunke ith' ship-wrack Tauerne. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Bellamont, Maybery, and Mistresse Maybery.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Come Wife, our two gallants will be here presently: I haue promist them the best of entertainment, with protestation neuer to reueale to thee their slander: I will haue thee beare thy selfe, as if thou madest a feast vpon Simon and Iudes day, to country Gentlewomen, that came to see the Pageant, bid them extreamly welcome, though thou wish their throats cut; 'tis in fashion.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: O God I shall neuer indure them.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Indure them, you are a foole: make it your case, as it may be many womens of the Freedome; that you had a friend in priuate, whom your husband should lay to his bosome: and he in requitall should lay his wife to his bosome: what treads of the toe, salutations by winckes, discourse by bitings of the lip, amorous glances, sweete stolne kisses when your husbands backs turn'd, would passe betweene them, beare your selfe to Greeneshield as if you did loue him for affecting you so intirely, not taking any notice of his iourney: theile put more tricks vpon you: you told me Greeneshield meanes to bring his Sister to your house, to haue her boord here.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Right, shee's some crackt demy-culuerin, that hath miscaried in seruice: no matter though it be some charge to me for a time I care not.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Lord was there euer such a husband?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Why, wouldst thou haue me suffer their tongues to run at large, in Ordinaries and Cock-pits; though the Knaues doe lye, I tell you Maister Bellamont, lyes that come from sterne lookes, and Sattin out-sides, and guilt Rapiers also, will be put vp and goe for currant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Right sir, 'tis a small sparke, giues fire to a beautifull womans discredit.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
I will therefore vse them like informing knaues in this kinde, make vp their mouthes with siluer, and after bee reveng'd vpon them: I was in doubt I should haue growne fat of late: & it were not for law suites: and feare of our wiues, we rich men
should grow out of all compasse: they come, my worthy friends welcome: looke my wiues colour rises already.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: You haue not made her acquainted with the discouery.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O by no meanes: yee see Gentlemen the affection of an old man; I would faine make all whole agen. Wife giue entertainment to our new acquaintance, your lips wife, any woman may lend her lips without her husbands priuity tis alowable.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You are very welcome; I thinke it be neere dinner time Gentlemen: Ile will the maide to couer, and returne presently.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Gods pretious why doth she leaue them? Exit.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O I know her stomack: shee is but retirde into another chamber, to ease her heart with crying a little: it hath euer bin her humor, she hath done it 5. or 6. times in a day, when Courtiers haue beene heare, if any thing hath bin out of order, and yet euery returne laught and bin as merry: & how is it Gentlemen, you are well acquainted with this roome, are you not?

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: I had a dellicate banquet once on that table.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: In good time: but you are better acquainted with my bed chamber.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Were the cloath of gold Cushins set forth at your entertainement?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: And the cloath of Tissew Valance.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: They are very rich ones.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: God refuse me, they are lying Rascols, I haue no such furniture.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I protest it was the strangest, and yet with-all the happiest fortune that wee should meete you two at Ware, that euer redeemed such desolate actions: I would not wrong you agen for a million of Londons.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: No, do you want any money? or if you be in debt, I am a hundreth pound ith' Subsidie, command mee.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Alas good Gentleman; did you euer read of the like pacience in any of your ancient Romans?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You see what a sweet face in a Veluet cap can do, your cittizens wiues are like Partriges, the hens are better than the cocks.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: I beleeue it in troth, Sir you did obserue how the Gentlewoman could not containe her selfe, when she saw vs enter.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: For thus much I must speake in allowance of her modestie, when I had her most priuate she would blush extreamely.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I, I warrant you, and aske you if you would haue such a great sinne lie vpon your conscience, as to lie with another mans wife.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Introth she would.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And tell you there were maides inough in london, if a man were so vitiously giuen, whose Portions would helpe them to husbands though gentlemen gaue the first onset.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: You are a merry ould gentleman infaith Sir: much like to this was her langwage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And yet clipe you with as voluntary a bosome; as if she had fallen in loue with you at some Innes a court reuels; and invited you by letter to her lodging.

sp.speaker: Fet.
sp.p: Your knowledge Sir, is perfect without any information.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Ile goe see what my wife is doing gentlemen, when my wife enters shew her this ring; and twill quit all suspition. Exit.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Dost heare Luke Greeshield wil thy wife by here presently.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I left my boy to waight vpon her, by this light, I thinke God prouides; for if this cittisen had not out of his ouerplus of kindnes proferd her, her diet and lodging vnder the name of my sister, I could not haue told what shift to haue made; for the greatest part of my mony is reuolted; weele make more vse of him, the whoresoÌ rich Inkeeper of Doncaster her father shewed himselfe a ranke ostler: to send her vp at this time a yeare; and and by the carier to, twas but a iades trike of him.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: But haue you instructed her to call you brother.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Yes and shele do it, I left her at Bosomes Inne, sheele be here, presently. Enter Maybery.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Maister Greenesheild your sister is come; my wife is entertaining her, by the masse I haue bin vpon her lips already, Lady you are welcome, looke you maister Greeneshield, because your sister is newly come out of the fresh aire, and that to be pent vp in a narrow lodging here ith' cittie may offend her health she shall lodge at a garden house of mine in Morefeilds where if it please you and my worthy friend heare to beare her company your seuerall lodgings and Ioint commons (to the poore ability of a cittizen) shalbe prouided.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: O God Sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Nay no complement your loues comand it: shalls to dinner Gentlemen, come maister Bellamont Ile be the Gentleman vsher to this faire Lady.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p:
Here is your ring Mistris; a thousand times,â and
would haue willingly lost my best of maintenance that I might haue found you haire so tractable.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Sir I am still my selfe, I know not by what means you haue grown vpon my husband, he is much deceaued in you I take it: will you go in to dinnerâ O God that I might haue my wil of him & it were not for my husband ide scratch out his eyes presently. Ex.

sp.speaker: Fet.
sp.p: Welcome to London bonny mistris Kate, thy husband little dreams of the familiarity that hath past betwene thee & I Kate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Noe matter if hee did: he ran away from me like a base slaue as he was, out of Yorke-shire, and pretended he would goe the Iland voiage, since I neere heard of him till within this fortnight: can the world condemne me for entertayning a friend, that am vsed so like an Infidel?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: I think not, but if your husband knew of this he'd be deuorst.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Hee were an asse then, no wisemen should deale by their wiues as the sale of ordinance passeth in England, if it breake the first discharge the workman is at the losse of it, if the second the Marchant, & the workman ioyntly, if the third the Marchant, so in our case, if a woman proue false the first yeare, turne her vpon her fathers neck, if the second, turne her home to her father but allow her a portion, but if she hould pure mettaile two yeare & flie to seueral peeces, in the third, repaire the ruines of her honesty at your charges, for the best peece of ordinance, may bee crackt in the casting, and for women to haue cracks and slaues, alas they are borne to them, now I haue held out foure yeare, doth my husband do any things about London doth he swagger?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: O as tame as a fray in Fleetestreet, when their are nobody to part them.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I euer thought so, we haue notable valiant fellowes about Doncaster, theile giue the lie and the stab both in an instant.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: You like such kind of man-hood best Kate.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Yes introth for I think any woman that loues her friend, had rather haue him stand by it then lie by it, but I pray thee tel me, why must I be quarterd at this Cittizens garden house, say you.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: The discourse of that wil set thy bloud on fire to be reuengd on thy husbands forhead peece. Ent. Bella. & Maist. Maybe.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Wil you go in to dinner sir?

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Wil you lead the way forsoth?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: No sweete forsothe weele follow you.
O Maister Bellamont: as euer you tooke pitty vpon the simplicity of a poore abused gentlewoman: wil you tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Any thing sweet Mistris Mayberrie.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I but will you doe it faithfully?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As I respect your acquaintance I shall doe it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Tell me then I beseech you, doe not you thinke this minx is some noughty packe whome my husband hath fallen in loue with, and meanes to keepe vnder my nose at his garden house.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No vpon my life is she not,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O I cannot beleeue it, I know by her eies she is not honest, why should my husband proffer them such kindnes? that haue abused him and me; so intollerable: and will not suffer me to speake; theres the hell ont not suffer me to speake.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fie fie, he doth that like a vserer, that will vse a man with all kindnes, that he may be carelesse of paying his mony, vpon his day, and after-wards take the extremitie of the forfature; your iealousie is Idle: say this were true, it lies in the bosome of a sweete wife to draw her husband from any loose imperfection, from wenching, from Iealosie, from couitousnes from crabbednes, which is the old mans common disease, by her politicke yealding.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She maye doe it from crabednes, for example I haue knowne as tough blades as any are in England broke vpon a fetherbed,â come to diner,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ile be ruled by you Sir, for you are very like mine vncle.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Suspition workes more mischiefe growes more strong, To seuer chast beds then aparant wrongs. Exit.

div.head: ACTVS 3. SAENA 1.
div.stage: Enter Doll, Chartly Leuerpoole and Phillip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Come my little Punke with thy two Compositors to this vnlawfull painting house, thy pounders a my old poeticall dad wilbe here presently, take vp thy State in this chayre, and beare thy selfe as if thou wert talking to thy pottecary after the receipt of a purgation: looke scuruily vpon him: sometimes be merrie and stand vppon thy pantoffles like a new elected scauinger.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: And by and by melancholicke like a Tilter that hath broake his staues foule before his Mistrisse.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Right, for hee takes thee to bee a woman of a great count: harke vpon my life hee's come.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: See who knocks: thou shalt see mee make a foole of a Poet, that hath made fiue hundred fooles.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Please your new Lady-ship hee's come.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Is hee? I should for the more state let him walke some two houres in an vtter roome: if I did owe him money, 'twere not much out of fashion; but come enter him: Stay, when we are in priuate conference send in my Tayler.

div.stage: Enter Bellamont brought in by Leuerpoole.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Looke you my Ladie's a sleepe, sheele wake presently.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I come not to teach a Starling sir, God-boy-you.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Nay, in trueth Sir, if my Lady should but dreame you had beene heare.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Who's that keepes such a prating?

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: 'Tis I Madam.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Ile haue you preferd to be a Cryer: you haue an exlent throate for't: pox a the Poet is he not come yet?

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Hee's here Madam.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Crie you mercy: I ha curst my Monkey for shrewd turnes a hundred times, and yet I loue it neuer the worse I protest.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Tis not in fashion deere Lady to call the breaking out of a Gentlewomans lips, scabs, but the heate of the Liuer.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: So sir: if you haue a sweete breath, and doe not smell of swetty linnen, you may draw neerer, neerer.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: I am no friend to Garlick Madam.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: You write the sweeter verse a great deale sir, I haue heard much good of your wit maister Poet: you do many deuises for Cittizens wiues: I care not greatly because I haue a Citty Laundresse already, if I get a Citty Poet too: I haue such a deuise for you, and this it is. Enter Tayler .O welcome Tayler: do but waite till I dispatch my Tayler, and Ile discouer my deuice to you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ile take my leaue of your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: No: I pray thee stay: I must haue you sweate for my deuice Maister Poet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He sweats already beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: A cup of wine there: what fashion will make a woman haue the best bodie Taylor.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: A short dutch wast with a round cathern-wheele fardingale: a close sleeue with a cartoose collour and a pickadell.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And what meate will make a woman haue a fine wit Maister Poet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Fowle madam is the most light, delicate, & witty feeding.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Fowle sayst thou: I know them that feede of it euery meale, and yet are as arrant fooles as any are in a kingdome of my credit: hast thou don Taylor? now to discouer my deuice sir: Ile drinck to you sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Gods pretious, wee nere thought of her deuice before, pray god it be any thing tollerable.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Ile haue you make 12. poesies for a dozen of cheese trenchers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O horrible!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: In welch madam?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Why in welch sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Because you will haue them seru'd in with your cheese Ladie.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I will bestow them indeede vpon a welch Captaine: one that loues cheese better than venson, for if you should but get 3. or 4. Cheshire cheeses and set them a running down Hiegate-hill, he would make more hast after them than after the best kennell of hounds in England; what think you of my deuice?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Fore-god a very strange deuice and a cunning one.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now he begins to eye the goblet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You should be a kin to the Bellamonts, you giue the same Armes madam.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Faith I paid sweetely for the cup, as it may be you and some other Gentleman haue don for their Armes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, the same waight: the same fashion: I had three nest of them giuen mee, by a Nobleman at the christing of my sonne Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Your sonne is come to full age sir: and hath tane possession of the gift of his God-father.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, thou wilt not kill mee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No sir, ile kill no Poet least his ghost write satires against me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Whats she? a good common welthes woman, shee was borne.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: For her Country, and has borne her Country.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Heart of vertue? what make I here?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: This was the party you rail'd on: I keepe no worse company than your selfe father, you were wont to say venery is like vsery that it may be allowed tho it be not lawfull.

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.p: Wherefore come I hither.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: To make a deuice for cheese-trenchers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ile tell you why I sent for you, for nothing but to shew you that your grauity may bee drawne in: white haires may fall into the company of drabs aswell as red beardes into the society of knaues: would not this woman deceiue a whole camp ith Low-countries, and make one Commander beleeue she only kept her cabbin for him, and yet quarter twenty more in't.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Pree the what doest thou think of me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I thinke thou art a most admirable, braue, beautifull Whore.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Nay sir, I was told you would raile: but what doe you thinke of my deuice sir, nay: but you are not to depart yet Maister Poet: wut sup with me? Ile cashiere all my yong barnicles, & weele talke ouer a peice of mutton and a partridge, wisely.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sup with thee that art a common vndertaker? thou that doest promise nothing but watchet eyes, bumbast calues and false perywigs.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Pree thee comb thy beard with a comb of black leade, it may be I shall affect thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O thy vnlucky starre! I must take my leaue of your worshippe I cannot fit your deuice at this instant: I must desire to borrow a nest of goblets of you: O villanie! I wud some honest Butcher would begge all the queanes and knaues ith Citty and cary them into some other Country they'd sell better than Beefes and Calues: what a vertuous Citty would this bee then! mary I thinke there would bee a few people left int, vds foot, guld with Cheese-trenchers and yokt in entertainment with a Taylor? good, good. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How doest Doll?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Scuruie, very scuruie.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Where shalls suppe wench?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p:
Ile suppe in my bedde: gette you home to your
lodging and come when I send for you, Ã´ filthy roague that I am.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How! how, mistris Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Saint Antonies fire light in your Spanish slops: vds life, ille make you know a difference, betweene my mirth and melancholy, you panderly roague.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: We obserue your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: The puncks in her humerâ pax. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Ile humor you and you pox mee: vds life haue I lien with a Spaniard of late, that I haue learnt to mingle such water with my Malago, Other's some scuruie thing or other breeding; how many seuerall loues of Plaiers of Vaulters, of Lieutenants haue I entertain'd besides a runner a the ropes, and now to let bloud when the signe is at the heart? should I send him a letter with some Iewel in't, he would requite it as lawiers do, that re-returne a wood-cock pie to their clients, when they send them a Bason and a Eure, I will instantly go and make my selfe drunke, till I haue lost my memory, liue a scoffing Poet? Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lep-frog and Squirill.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.p: Now Squirill wilt thou make vs acquainted with the iest thou promist to tell vs of?

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: I will discouer it, not as a Darby-shere women discouers her great teeth, in laughter: but softly as a gentleman courts a wench behind an Arras: and this it is, yong Greenesheild thy Maister with Greenesheilds sister lie in my maisters garden-house here in More-fields.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.p: Right, what of this?

sp.speaker: Squir
sp.p: Mary sir if the Gentlewoman be not his wife, he commits incest, for Ime sure he lies with her euery night.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: All this I know, but to the rest.

sp.speaker: Squir.
sp.p: I will tell thee, the most pollitick trick of a woman, that ere made a mans face looke witherd and pale like the tree in Cuckolds Hauen in a great snow: and this it is, my mistris makes her husband belieue that shee walkes in her sleepe a nights, and to confirme this beleefe in him, sondry times shee hath rizen out of her bed, vnlockt all the dores, gon from Chamber to Chamber, opend her chests, touz'd among her linnen, & when he hath wakte & mist her, comming to question why she coniur'd thus at midnight, he hath found her fast a sleepe, mary it was Cats sleepe, for you shall heare what prey she watcht for.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.p: Good; forth.

sp.speaker: Squir.
sp.p: I ouer-heard her last night talking with thy Maister, and she promist him that assoone as her husband was a sleepe, she would walke according to her custome, and come to his Chamber, marry shee would do it so puritannically, so secretly I meane that no body should heare of it.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.p: Ist possible?

sp.speaker: Squir.
sp.p: Take but that corner and stand close, and thine eyes shall witnesse it.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.p: O intollerable witte, what hold can any man take of a womans honesty.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Hold? no more hold then of a Bull noynted with Sope, and baited with a shoale of Fidlers in Staffordshire: stand close I heare her comming. Enter Kate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: What a filthy knaue was the shoo-maker, that made my slippers, what a creaking they keepe: O Lord, if there be any power that can make a womans husband sleepe soundly at a pinch, as I haue often read in foolish Poetrie that there is, now, now, and it be thy will, let him dreame some fine dreame or other, that hee's made a Knight, or a Noble-man, or some-what whilst I go and take but two kisses, but two kisses from sweete Fetherstone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Sfoot hee may well dreame hees made a Knight: for Ile be hangd if she do not dub him.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Was there euer any walking spirit, like to my wife? what reason should there bee in nature for this; I will question some Phisition: not heare neither: vdslife, I would laugh if she were in Maister Fetherstones Chamber, shee would fright him, Maister Fetherstone, Maister Fetherstone.

sp.speaker: Within Fether.
sp.p: Ha, how now who cals?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Did you leaue your doore open last night?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: I know not, I thinke my boy did.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Gods light shee's there then, will you know the iest, my wife hath her old tricks, Ile hold my life, my wife's in your chamber, rise out of your bed, and see and you can feele her.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: He will feele her I warrant you?

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Haue you her sir?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Not yet sir, shees here sir.

div.stage: Enter Fetherstone and Kate in his armes.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p:
So I said euen now to my selfe before God la: take her vp in your armes, and bring her hether softly, for feare of waking
her: I neuer knew the like of this before God la, alas poore Kate, looke before God; shees a sleepe with her eyes open: prittie little roague, Ile wake her, and make her ashamd of it.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: O youle make her sicker then.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I warrant you; would all women thought no more hurt then thou doost, now sweet villaine, Kate, Kate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I longd for the merry thought of a phesant.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: She talkes in her sleepe.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: And the foule-gutted Tripe-wife had got it, & eate halfe of it: and my colour went and came, and my stomach wambled: till I was ready to sound, but a Mid-wife perceiued it, and markt which way my eyes went; and helpt mee to it, but Lord how I pickt it, 'twas the sweetest meate me thought.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: O pollitick Mistrisse.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Why Kate, Kate?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I beshrew your hart, Lord where am I?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I pray thee be not frighted.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O I am sick, I am sick, I am sick, O how my flesh trembles: oh some of the Angelica water, I shal haue the Mother presently.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Hold downe her stomach good maister Fetherstone, while I fetch some. Exit.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Well dissembled Kate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Pish, I am like some of your Ladies that can be sick when they haue no stomack to lie with their husbands.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: What mischiuous fortune is this: weel haue a iourney to Ware Kate, to redeeme this misfortune.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Well, Cheaters do not win all wayes: that woman that will entertaine a friend, must as well prouide a Closet or Back-doore for him, as a Fether-bed.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Be my troth I pitty thy husband.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Pitty him, no man dares call him Cuckold; for he weares Sattin: pitty him, he that will pull downe a mans signe, and set vp hornes, there's law for him.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Be sick againe, your husband comes.

div.stage: Enter Greeneshield with a broken shin.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I haue the worst luck; I thinke I get more bumps and shrewd turnes ith' darke, how do's she maister Fetherstone.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Very ill sir; shees troubled with the moother extreamly, I held downe her belly euen now, and I might feele it rise.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O lay me in my bed, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: I will finde a remedy for this walking, if all the Docters in towne can sell it; a thousand pound to a penny she spoile not her face, or breake her neck, or catch a cold that shee may nere claw off againe, how doost wench?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: A little recouerd; alas I haue so troubled that Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: None ith' world Kate, may I do you any farther seruice.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: And I were where I would be in your bed: pray pardon me, wast you Maister Fetherstone, hem, I should be well then.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Marke how she wrings him by the fingers.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Good night, pray you giue the Gentleman thankes for patience.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Good night Sir.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: You haue a shrewd blow, you were best haue it searcht.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: A scratch, a scratch. Exit.

sp.speaker: Feth
sp.p: Let me see what excuse should I frame, to get this wench forth a towne with me: Ile perswade her husband to take Phisick, and presently haue a letter framed, from his father in law, to be deliuerd that morning for his wife, to come and receiue some small parcell of money in Enfield chase, at a Keepers that is her Vncle, then sir he not beeing in case to trauell, will intreate me to accompany his wife, weele lye at Ware all night, and the next morning to London, Ile goe strike a Tinder, and frame a Letter presently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: And Ile take the paines to discouer all this to my maister old Maybery, there hath gone a report a good while, my Maister hath vsed them kindly, because they haue beene ouer familiar with his wife, but I see which way Fetherstone lookes. sfoote ther's neare a Gentleman of them all shall gull a Citizen, & thinke to go scot-free: though your commons shrinke for this be but secret, and my Maister shall intertaine thee, make thee insteed of handling false Dice, finger nothing but gold and siluer wagge, an old Seruing-man turnes to a young beggar, whereas a young Prentise may turne to an old Alderman, wilt be secret?

sp.speaker: Leap.
sp.p: O God sir, as secret as rushes in an old Ladyes Chamber. Exit.

div.head: ACTVS 4. SCENA 1.
div.stage: Enter Bellamont in his Night-cap, with leaues in his hand, his man after him with lights, Standish and Paper.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sirra, Ile speake with none.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Not a plaier:

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No tho a Sharer ball,
Ile speake with none altho it be the mouth
Of the big company, Ile speake with none,â away.
sp.p: Why should not I bee an excellent statesman? I can in the wryting of a tragedy, make Caesar speake better than euer his ambition could: when I write of Pompey I haue Pompeies soule within me, and when I personate a worthy Poet, I am then truly my selfe, a poore vnpreferd scholler.

div.stage: Enter his Man hastily.

sp.speaker: Seru,
sp.p: Here's a swaggering fellow sir, that speakes not like a man of gods making, sweares he must speake with you and wil speake with you.

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.p: Not of gods making what is he? a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: He's a Gentleman sir, by his clothes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Enter him and his clothes: clothes sometimes are better Gentlemen than their Maisters. Ent. the Captaine & the Ser. is this he? Seeke you me sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I seeke sir, (god plesse you) for a Sentillman, that talkes besides to himselfe when he's alone, as if hee were in Bed-lam, and he's a Poet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So sir it may bee you seeke mee, for Ime sometimes out a my wits.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You are a Poet sir, are you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ime haunted with a Fury Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Pray Maister Poet shute off this little pot-gun, and I wil coniure your Fury: tis well lay you sir, my desires are to haue some amiable and amorous sonnet or madrigall composed by your Fury, see you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Are you a louer sir of the nine Muses.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ow, by gad out a cry.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Y'are then a scholler sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I ha pickt vp my cromes in Sesus colledge in Oxford one day a gad while agoe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Y'are welcome y'are very welcome, Ile borrow your Iudgement looke you sir, Ime writyng a Tragedy, the Tragedy of young Astianax.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Styanax Tragedy is he liuing can you tell? was not Stianax a mammouth man?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O no sir, you mistake, he was a Troyane great Hectors Son.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hector was grannam to Cadwallader, when shee was great with child, god vdge me, there was one young Styanan of Mon-mouth sheire was a madder greeke as any is in al England.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This was not he assure yee: looke you sir, I will haue this Tragedy presented in the French Court, by French Gallants.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By god your Frenchmen will doe a Tragedy enterlude, poggy well.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It shalbe sir at the marriages of the Duke of Orleans, and Chatilion the admiral of France, the stage.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Vds bloud, does Orleans marry with the Admirall of France now.

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.p: O sir no, they are two seuerall marriages. As I was saying the stage hung all with black veluet, and while tis acted, my self wil stÃ¡d behind the Duke of Biron, or some other cheefe minion or so,â who shall, I they shall take some occasion about the musick of the fourth Act, to step to the French King, and say, Sire, voyla, il et votre treshumble seruiteur, le plu sage, Ã¨ diuino espirit, monsieur Bellamont, all in French thus poynting at me, or you is the learned old English Gentleman Maister Bellamont a very worthie man, to bee one of your priuy Chamber, or Poet Lawreat.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But are you sure Duke Pepper-noone wil giue you such good vrdes, behind your back to your face.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh I, I, I man, he's the onely courtier that I know there: but what do you thinke that I may come to by this.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: God vdge mee, all France may hap die in your debt for this.

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.p: I am now wryting the description of his death.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Did he die in his ped.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You shall heare: suspition is the Mynion of great hearts, no: I will not begin there: Imagine a great man were to be executed about the 7. houre in a gloomy morning.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: As it might bee Sampson or so, or great Golias that was kild by my Countriman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Right sir, thus I expresse it in yong Astianax.
Now the wilde people greedy of their griefes,
Longing to see, that which their thoughts abhord,
Preuented day, and rod on their owne roofes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Could the little horse that ambled on the top of Paulest cary all the people; els how could they ride on the roofes!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O sir, tis a figure in Poetry, marke how tis followed,
Rod on their owne roofes,
Making all Neighboring houses tilde with men; tilde with men ist not good.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By Sesu, and it were tilde all with naked Imen twere better.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You shall heare no more; pick your eares, they are fowle sir, what are you sir pray?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A Captaine sir, and a follower of god Mars.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Mars, Bachus, and I loue Apollo! a Captaine! then I pardon your sir, and Captaine what wud you presse me for?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: For a witty ditty, to a Sentill-oman, that I am falne in with all, ouer head and eares in affections, and naturall desires.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: An Acrostick were good vpon her name me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Crosse sticks: I wud not be too crosse Maister Poet; yet if it bee best to bring her name in question, her name is mistris Dorothy Hornet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The very consumption that wasts my Sonne, and the Ayme that hung lately vpon mee: doe you loue this Mistris Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Loue her! there is no Captaines wife in England, can haue more loue put vpon her, and yet Ime sure Captaines wiues, haue their pellies full of good mens loues.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: And does she loue you? has there past any great matter betweene you?

sp.speaker: Cap.
