sp.p: As great a matter, as a whole coach, and a horse and his wife are gon too and fro betweene vs.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is shee? ifayth Captaine, bee valiant and tell trueth, is she honest?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Honest? god vdge me, shee's as honest, as a Punck, that cannot abide fornication, and lechery.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Looke you Captaine, Ile shew you why I aske, I hope you thinke my wenching daies are past, yet Sir, here's a letter that her father, brought me from her and inforc'd mee to take this very day. Enter a Seruant and Whispers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Tis for some loueâ song to send to me, I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This falls out pat, my man tells mee, the party is at my dore, shall she come in Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O I, I, put her in, put her in I pray now. Exit Seru.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The letter saies here, that she's exceeding sick, and intreates me to visit her: Captaine, lie you in ambush behind the hangings, and perhaps you shall heare the peece of a Commedy: she comes, she comes, make your selfe away.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Does the Poet play Torkin and cast my Lucrasies water too in hugger muggers? if he do, Styanax Tragedy was neuer so horrible bloudy-minded, as his Commedy shalbe,â Tawsons Captaine Ienkins. Enter Doll.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Now Maister Poet, I sent for you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And I came once at your Ladiships call.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: My Ladiship and your Lordship lie both in one manner; you haue coniur'd vp a sweete spirit in mee haue you not Rimer?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why Medea! what spirit! wud I were a young man for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: So wud I, for then thou couldst doe mee no hurt; now thou doest.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If I were a yonker, it would be no Imodesty in me to bee seene in thy company; but to haue snow in the lap of Iune; vile! vile: yet come; garlick has a white head, and a greene stalke, then why should not I? lets bee merry: what saies the diuill to al the world, for Ime sure thou art carnally possest with him.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Thou hast a filthy foot, a very filthy cariers foote.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A filthy shooe, but a fine foote, I stand not vpon my foote I.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What stands he vpon then? with a pox god blesse vs?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: A legge and a Calfe! I haue had better of a butcher fortie times for carrying a body! not worth begging by a Barber-surgeon.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Very good, you draw me and quarter me, fates keepe me from hanging.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p:
And which most turnes vp a womans stomach, thou art an old hoary man: thou hast gon ouer the bridge of many years, and now art ready to drop into a graue: what doe I see then
in that withered face of thine?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Wrinkles: grauity.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Wretchednes: griefe: old fellow thou hast be witch me; I can neither eate for thee, nor sleepe for thee, nor lie quietly in my bed for thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Vds blood! I did neuer see a white flea before I will clinge you?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I was borne sure in the dog dayes Ime so vnluky; I, in whome neither a flaxen haire, yellow beard, French doublet, nor Spanish hose, youth nor personage, rich face nor mony cold euer breed a true loue to any, euer to any man, am now besotted, doate, am mad, for the carcas of a man, and as if I were a baud, no ring pleases me but a deaths head.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sesu, are I men so arsy varsy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Mad for me? why if the worme of lust were wrigling within mee as it does in others, dost thinke Ide crawle vpon thee; wud I low after thee, that art a common calfe-bearer.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I confesse it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Doe you, are you a towne cowe and confesse you beare calues.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I confesse, I haue bin an Inne for any guest.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A pogs a your stable-roome; is your Inne a baudy house now?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I confesse (for I ha bin taught to hide nothing from my Suergeon and thou art he) I confesse that old stinking Surgeon like thy selfe) whom I call father, that Hornet neuer sweat for me, Ime none of his making.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You lie he makes you a punke Hornet minor.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Hees but a cheater, and I the false die hee playes withall, I power all my poyson out before thee, because heareafter I will be cleane: shun me not, loath me not, mocke me not, plagues confound thee, I hate thee to the pit of hell, yet if thou goest thither, ile follow thee, run, ayde doe what thou canst, ile run and ride ouer the world after thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Cockatrice: you mistris Salamanders that feare no burning, let my mare and my mares horse, and my coach come running home agen and run to an hospitall, and your Surgeons, and to knaues and panders and to the tiuell and his tame to.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Fiend art thou raized to torment me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Shee loues you Captaine honestly.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ile haue any man, oman or child by his eares, that saies a common drab can loue a Sentillman honestly, I will sell my Coach for a cart to haue you to puncks hall, Pridewell, I sarge you in Apollos name, whom you belong to, see her forth-comming, till I come and tiggle her, by and by, Sbloud I was neuer Couzend with a more rascall peece of mutton, since I came out a the Lawer Countries. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My dores are open for thee, be gon: woman!

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: This goatesâ peezle of thineâ

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Away: I loue no such implements in my house.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Doest not? am I but an implement? by all the maiden-heads that are lost in London in a yeare (& thats a great oth) for this trick, other manner of women than my selfe shall come to this house only to laugh at thee; and if thou wouldst labour thy heart out, thou shalt not do withal. Exit. Enter Seruant.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is this my Poeticall fury? how now sir!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Maister Maybery and his wife sir ith next roome.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What are they doing sir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Nothing sir, that I see, but onely wud speake with you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Enter 'em: this house wilbe to hot for mee, if this wench cast me into these sweates, I must shift my selfe, for pure necessity, haunted with sprites in my old daies!

div.stage: Enter Maybery booted, his Wife with him.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: A Commedy, a Canterbury tale smells not halfe so sweete as the Commedy I haue for thee old Poet: thou shalt write vpon't Poet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay I will write vpon't ift bee a Commedie, for I haue beene at a most villanous female Tragedie: come, the plot, the plot.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Let your man giue you the bootes presently, the plot lies in Ware my white Poet: Wife thou and I this night, will haue mad sport in Ware, marke me well Wife, in Ware.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: At your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Nay it shalbe at your pleasure Wife: looke you sir, looke you: Fetherstones boy (like an honest crack-halter) layd open all to one of my prentices, (for boies you know like women loue to be doing.)

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Very good: to the plot.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Fetherstone like a crafty mutton-monger, perswades Greenshield to be run through the body.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Strange! through the body?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I man, to take phisick: he does so, hee's put to his purgation; then sir what does me Fetherstone, but counterfits a letter from an Inkeeper of Doncaster, to fetch Greenshield (who is needy you know) to a keepers lodge in Enfeild-chace, a certaine Vncle, where Greenshield should receiue mony due to him in behalfe of his wife.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: His wife! is Greensheild married? I haue heard him sweare he was a batchiler.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: So haue I a hundred times.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: The knaue has more wiues than the Turke, he has a wife almost in euery shire in England, this parcel Gentlewoman is that Inkeepers Daughter of Doncaster.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hath she the entertainement of her fore-fathers? wil she keepe all commers company?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: She help's to passe away stale Capons, sower wine, and musty prouander: but to the purpose, this traine was layd by the baggage her selfe and Fetherstone, who it seemes makes her husband a vnicorne: and to giue fire to't, Greensheild like an Arrant wittall intreates his friend, to ride before his wife, and fetch the money, because taking bitter pills, he should proue but a loose fellow if he went, and so durst not go.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And so the poore Stag is to bee hunted in Enfeild-chace

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: No sir, Maister poet there you misse the plot. Fetherstone and my Lady Greensheild are rid to batter away their light commodities in Ware, Enfeild-chace is to cold for 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In Ware!

sp.speaker: May
sp.p: In durty Ware: I forget my selfe wise, on with your ryding suite and cry North-ward hoe, as the boy at Powles saies, let my Prentice get vp before thee, and man thee to Ware, lodge in the Inne I told thee, spur cut and away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Stay, stay, whats the bottom of this riddle? why send you her away?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
For a thing my little hoary Poet: looke thee, I smelt out my noble stincker Greensheild in his Chamber, and as tho
my heart stringes had bin crackt, I wept, and sighd, & thumpd, and thumpd, and rau'd and randed, and raild, and told him how my wife was now growne as common as baibery, and that shee had hierd her Taylor to ride with her to Ware, to meete a Gentleman of the Court.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Good; and how tooke he this drench downe.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Like Egs and Muscadine, at a gulp: hee cries out presently, did not I tell you old man, that sheel win my game when she came to bearing? hee railes vpon her, wills me to take her in the Act; to put her to her white sheete, to bee diuorc'd, and for all his guts are not fully scourd by his Pottecary, hee's pulling on his bootes, & will ride along with vs; lets muster as many as wee can.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It wilbe excellent sport, to see him and his owne wife meete in Ware, wilt not? I, I, weele haue a whole Regiment of horse with vs.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I stand vpon thornes, tel I shake him bith hornes: come, bootes boy, we must gallop all the way, for the Sin you know is done with turning vp the white of an eye, will you ioyne your forces.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Like a Hollander against a Dunkirke.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.l: March then, this curse is on all letchers throwne,
They giue hornes and at last, hornes are their owne. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Captaine Ienkins, and Allom.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Set the best of your little diminitiue legges before, and ride post I pray.

sp.speaker: Allo.
sp.p: Is it possible that mistris Doll should bee so bad?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Possible! Sbloud tis more easie for an oman to be naught, than for a soldier to beg, and thats horrible easie, you know.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I but to connicatch vs all so grosly.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Your Norfolke tumblers are but zanyes to connicatching punckes.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Shee gelded my purse of fifty pounds in ready money.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
I will geld all the horses in fiue hundred Sheires, but I will ride ouer her, and her cheaters, and her Hornets; Shee made a starke Asse of my Coach-horse, and there is a putter-box, whome shee spred thick vpon her white bread, and eate him vp, I thinke shee has sent the poore fellow to Gilderland, but I will marse prauely in and out, and packe
agen vpon all the low countries in Christendom, as Holland and Zeland and Netherland, and Cleueland too, and I will be drunke and cast with maister Hans van Belch, but I will smell him out.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Doe so and weele draw all our arrowes of reuenge vp to the head but weele hit her for her villany.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I will traw as petter, and as vrse weapons as arrewes vp to the head, lug you, it shalbe warrants to giue her the whippe deedle.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: But now she knowes shees discouered, sheele take her bells and fly out of our reach.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Fie with her pells! ownds I know a parish that sal tag downe all the pells and sell em to Capten Ienkens, to do him good. and if pelle will fly, weele flie too, vnles, the pell-ropes hang vs: will you amble vp and downe to maister Iustice by my side, to haue this rascall Hornet in corum, and so, to make her hold her whoars peace.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Ile amble or trot with you Capten: you told me, she threatened her champions should cut for her, if so, wee may haue the peace of her.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O mon du! u dguin! follow your leader, Ienken shall cut, and Slice, as worse as they: come I scorne to haue any peace of her, or of any onam, but open warres. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Bellamont, Maybery, Greensheild, Phillip, Leuarpoole, Chartley: all booted.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What? will these yong Gentlemen to helpe vs to catch this fresh Salmon, ha! Phillip! are they thy friends.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We are beholding to you Gentlmen that youle fill our consort I ho seene your faces me thinkes before; and I cannot informe my selfe where.

sp.speaker: Both,
sp.p: May be so Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Shalls to horse, hears a tickler: heigh: to horse.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Come Switts and Spurres! lets mount our Cheualls: merry quoth a.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Gentlemen shall I shoote a fooles bolt out among you all, because weele be sure to be merry.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: What ist?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: For mirth on the high way, will make vs rid ground faster then if theeues were at our tayles, what say yee to this, lets all practise iests one against another, and hee that has the best iest throwne vpon him, and is most gald, betweene our riding foorth and comming in, shall beare the charge of the whole iourney.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Content ifaith.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Wee shall fitte one a you with a Cox-combe at Ware I beleeue.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Ist a bargen.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: And hands clapt vpon it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Stay, yonders the Dolphin without Bishops-gate, where our horses are at rack and manger, and wee are going past it: come crosse ouer: and what place is this?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Bedlam ist not?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Where the mad-men are, I neuer was amongst them, as you loue me Gentlemen, lets see what Greekes are within.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Wee shall stay too long.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not a whit, Ware will stay for our comming I warrant you: come a spurt and away, lets bee mad once in our dayes: this is the doore. Enter Full-moone.

sp.speaker: May,
sp.p: Saue you sir, may we see some a your mad-folkes, doe you keepe em?

sp.speaker: Full.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray bestow your name sir vpon vs.

sp.speaker: Full.
sp.p: My name is Full-moone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You well deserue this office good maister Full-moone: and what mad-caps haue you in your house,

div.stage: Enter the Phisition.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Diuerse.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Gods so, see, see, whats hee walkes yonder, is he mad.

sp.speaker: Full.
sp.p: Thats a Musition, yes hee's besides himselfe.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Musition, how fell he mad for Gods sake?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: For loue of an Italian Dwarfe.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Has he beene in Italy then?

sp.speaker: Full.
sp.p: Yes and speakes they say all manner of languages.

div.stage: Enter the Bawd.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Gods so, looke, looke, whats shee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The dancing Beare: a pritty well-fauourd little woman.

sp.speaker: Full.
sp.p: They say, but I know not, that she was a Bawd, and was frighted out of her wittes by fire,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: May we talke with 'em maister Ful-moone

sp.speaker: Full.
sp.p: Yes and you will; I must looke about for I haue vnruly tenants. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What haue you in this paper honest friend?

sp.speaker: Gree
sp.p: Is this he has al manner of languages, yet speakes none

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: How doe you Sir Andrew, will you send for some aquauite for me, I haue had no drinke neuer since the last great raine that fell.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No thats a lye.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Nay by gad, then you lie, for all y'are Sir Andrew, I was a dapper rogue in Portingall voiage, not an inch broad at the heele, and yet thus high, I scornd I can tell you to be druncke with raine water then Sir, In those golden and siluer dayes: I had sweete bitts then Sir Andrew: how doe you good brother Timothy?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: You haue bin in much trouble since that voiage.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Neuer in bride-wel I protest, as Ime a virgin: for I could neuer abide that bride-wel I protest, I was once sicke, and I tooke my water in a basket, and cary'd it to a doctors.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: In a basket.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Yes Sir: you arrant foole there was a vrinall in it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: The Doctor told me I was with child, how many Lords Knights, Gentlemen, Cittizens, and others promist me to be god-fathers to that child: twas not Gods will: the prentises made a riot vpon my glasse-windowes the Shroue-tuesday following and I miscaried.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: O doe not weepe.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: I ha cause to weepe: I trust Gintlewomen their diet sometimes a fortnight: lend Gentlemen holland shirts, and they sweat 'em out at tennis: and no restitution, and no restitution. but Ile take a new order, I will haue but six stewd prunes in a dish and some of mother Walls cakes: for my best customers are taylors.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Taylors! ha ha.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: I Taylors: giue me your London Prentice; your country Gentlemen are growne too polliticke.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But what say you to such young Gentlemen as these are.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Foh, they as soone as they come to their lands get vp to London, and like squibs that run vpon lynes, they keepe
a Spitting of fire, and cracking till they ha spent all, and when my squib is out, what sayes his punke, foh, he stinckes.

lg.l: Me thought this other night, I saw a pretty sight,
A comely country mayd, not squeamish nor afraid,
I sold her maiden-head once, and I sold her maiden-head twice,
And I sould it last to an Alderman of Yorke.
And then I had sold it thrice.

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: You sing scuruily.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: mary muffe, sing thou better, for Ile goe sleepe my old sleepes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What are you a doing my friend.

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: Pricking, pricking.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What doe you meane by pricking?

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: A Gentleman like quallity.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This fellow is some what prouder, and sullener then the other.

sp.speaker: May,
sp.p: Oh; so be most of your musitions.

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: Are my teeth rotten?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: Then I am no Comfit-maker, nor Vintner, I doe not get wenches in my drincke: are you a musition?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p: weele be sworne brothers then, looke you sweete roague.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Gods so, now I thinke vpon't, a Iest is crept into my head, steale away, if you loue me. Exeunt: musition sings.

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: Was euer any marchants band set better I set it: walke Ime a cold, this white sattin is to thin vnles it be cut, for then the Sunne enters: can you speake Italian too, Sapete Italiano.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Vn poco.

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: Sblood if it be in you, Ile poike it out if you; vn poco, come March lie heare with me but till the fall of the lease, and if you haue but poco Italiano in you, Ile fill you full of more poco March.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come on. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Maybery, Greenshielde, Phillip. Full-moone. Leuerpoole, and Chartely.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Good Maister Mayberie, Philip, if you be kind Gentlemen vphold the iest: your whole voiage is payd for.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Follow it then.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: The old Gentleman say you, why he talkt euen now aswell in his wittes as I do my selfe, and lookt as wisely.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: No matter how he talkes, but his Pericranion's perisht.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Where is he pray?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Mary with the Musition, and is madder by this time

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Hee's an excellent Musition himselfe, you must note that.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: And hauing met one fit for his one tooth: you see hee skips from vs.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: The troth is maister Full-moone, diuers traines haue bin laide to bring him hither, without gaping of people, and neuer any tooke effect till now.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: How fell he mad?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: For a woman, looke you sir: here's a crowne to prouide his supper: hee's a Gentleman of a very good house, you shall bee paid well if you conuert him; to morrow morning, bedding, and a gowne shall be sent in, and wood and coale.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Nay sir, he must ha no fire.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: No, why looke what straw you buy for him, shall returne you a whole haruest.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Let his straw be fresh and sweet we beseech you sir?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Get a couple of your sturdiest fellowes, and bind him I pray, whilst wee slip out of his sight.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Ile hamper him, I warrant Gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: But how will my noble Poet take it at my hands, to betray him thus.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Foh, tis but a iest, he comes.

div.stage: Enter Musition and Bellamont.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Perdonate mi, si Io dimando del vostro nome: oh, whether shrunke you: I haue had such a mad dialogue here.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Wee ha bin with the other mad folkes.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: And what sayes he and his prick-song?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Wee were vp to the eares in Italian ifaith.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: In Italian; O good maister Bellamont lets heare him.

div.stage: Enter Full-moone, and two Keepers.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How now, Sdeath what do you meane? are you mad?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Away sirra, bind him, hold fast: you want a wench sirra, doe you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What wench? will you take mine armes from me, being no Heralds? let goe you Dogs.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Bind him, be quiet: come, come, dogs, fie, & a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Maister Maibery, Philip, maister Maibery, vds foot.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Ile bring you a wench, are you mad for a wench.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I hold my life my comrads haue put this fooles cap vpon thy head: to gull me: I smell it now: why doe you heare Full-moone, let me loose; for Ime not mad; Ime not mad by Iesu:

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Aske the Gentlemen that.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: byth Lord I'me aswell in my wits, as any man ith' house, & this is a trick put vpon thee by these gallants in pure knauery.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Ile trie that, answer me to this question: loose his armes a little, looke you sir, three Geese nine pence; euery Goose three pence, whats that a Goose, roundly, roundly one with another.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sfoot do you bring your Geese for me to cut vp.

div.stage: Enter all.
strike him soundly, and kick him.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Hold, hold, bind him maister Full-moone.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Binde him you, hee has payd me all, Ile haue none of his bonds not I, vnlesse I could recouer them better.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Haue I giuen it you maister Poet, did the Lime-bush take.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It was his warrant sent thee to Bedlam, old Iack Bellamont, and maister Full-ith'moone, our warrant discharges him; Poet, weele all ride vpon thee to Ware, & back agen I feare to thy cost.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If you doe, I must beare you, thanke you Maister Greenshield, I will not dye in your debt: farewell you mad rascals, to horse come, 'tis well done; 'twas well done, you may laugh, you shall laugh Gentlemen: if the gudgeon had beene swallowed by one of you it had bin vile, but by Gad 'tis nothing, for your best Poets indeed are madde for the most part: farewell good-man Full-moone.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen if you come by call in. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, yes, when they are mad, horse your selues now if you be men.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.l: Hee gallop must that after women rides,
Get our wiues out of Towne, they take long strides. Exeunt.

div.head: ACTVS 5. SCAENA 1.
div.stage: Enter old Maybery and Bellamont.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
But why haue you brought vs to the wrong Inne? and withall possest Greenshield that my wife is not in towne: when my proiect was, that I would haue brought him vp into the
chamber, where yong Fetherstone and his wife lay: and so all his Artillery should haue recoild into his owne bosome.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O it will fall out farre better, you shall see my reuenge will haue a more neate and vnexpected conueyance: he hath bin all vp and downe the towne, to enquire for a Londoners wife, none such is to be found: for I haue mewd your wife vp already. mary he heres of a Yorke-shire Gentlewoman at next Inne, and thats all the commodity Ware affoords at this instant: now sir, he very pollitickly imagins, that your wife is rode to Puckridge, fiue mile further, for saith he in such a towne where Hosts will be familiar, and Tapsters saucie, & Chamberlaines worse then theeues intelligencers, theile neuer put foot out of Stirrop: either at Pucridge or Wades-mill (saith he) you shall finde them: & because our horses are weary, hee's gone to take vp Post: my counsaile is onely this, when he comes in, faine your selfe very melancholie, sweare you will ride no farther, and this is your part of the Comedy: the sequell of the iest shall come like money borrowed of a Courtier, and paid within the day, a thing strange & vnexpected. Enter Greeneshield.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Inough, I ha't,

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.p: He comes.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Come gallants, the post horse are ready, tis but a quarter of an houres riding, weele ferrit them and firke them in-faith.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Are they growne pollitick? when do you see honesty couet corners, or a gentleman thats no thiefe lie in the Inne of a carrier.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: Nothing hath vndone my wife, but too much riding.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: She was a pritty piece of a Poet indeed, & in her discourse would as many of your Gold-smiths wiues doe, draw her simily from pretious stones, so wittily, as redder then your Ruby, harder then your Diamond, and so from stone to stone, in lesse time then a man can draw on a straight boote, as if she had beene an excellent Lapidary.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Come will you to horse sir?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: No let her go to the diuell and she will, Ile not stirre a foote further.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Gods pretious ist come to this: perswade him as you are a Gentleman, there will be ballads made of him, & the burthen thereof will be, if you had rode out 5. mile forward, he had found the fatall house of Braineford North-ward, O hone, hone, hone ononero.

sp.speaker: Bell,
sp.p: You are merry sir.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Like your Cittizen, I neuer thinke of my debts, when I am a horseback.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You imagin you are riding from your creditors.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Good infaith: wil you to horse?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Ile ride no further.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Then ile discharge the post-maister: was't not a pritty wit of mine maister Poet to haue had him rod into Puckridge, with a horne before him, ha wast not?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good sooth excellent: I was dull in apprehending it: but come since we must stay: wele be mery, chamberlaine call in the musick, bid the Tapsters & maids come vp and dance, what weel make a night of it, harke you maisters, I haue an exellent iest to make old Maibery merry, Sfoote weele haue him merry.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Lets make him drunke then, a simple catching wit I.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Go thy waies, I know a Nobleman would take such a delight in thee.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Why so he would in his foole.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Before God but hee would make a difference, hee would keepe you in Sattin, but as I was a saying weel haue him merry: his wife is gon to Puckridge, tis a wench makes him melancholy, tis a wench must make him mery: we must help him to a wench. when your cittizen comes into his Inne, wet & cold, dropping, either the hostis or one of her maids, warmes his bed, puls on his night-cap, cuts his cornes puts out the candle, bids him command ought, if he want ought: and so after maister cittiner sleepes as quietly, as if he lay in his owne low-country of Holland, his own linnen I meane sir, we must haue a wench for him.

sp.speaker: Gree
sp.p: But wher's this wench to be found, here are al the moueable peticotes of the house.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: At the next Inne there lodged to nightâ

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Gods pretious a Yorkeshire Gentlewoman; I ha't, Ile angle for her presently, weele haue him merry.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Procure some Chamberlaine to Pander for you.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: No Ile be Pander my selfe, because weele be merry.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Will you, will you?

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: But how? be a Pander as I am a gentleman? that were horrible, Ile thrust my self into the out-side of a Fawlconer in towne here: & now I thinke on't there are a company of country plaiers, that are come to towne here, shall furnish mee with haire and beard: if I do not bring her,â wilbe wondrous merry.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: About it looke you sir, though she beare her far aloofe, and her body out of distance, so her mind be comming 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Get old Maibery merry: that any man should take to heart thus the downe fall of a woman, I thinke when he comes home poore snaile, heele not dare to peepe forth of doores least his hornes vsher him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Go thy wayes, there be more in England weare large eares and hornes, then Stagges and Asses: excellent hee rides poste with a halter about his neck.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: How now wilt take?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Beyond expectation: I haue perswaded him the onely way to make you merry, is to helpe you to a wench, and the foole is gone to pander his owne wife hether.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Why heele know her?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: She hath beene maskt euer since she came into the Inne, for feare of discouery.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Then sheele know him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: For that his owne vnfortunate wit helpt my lasie inuention, for he hath disguisd himselfe like a Fawkner, in Towne heare, hoping in that procuring shape, to doe more good vpon her, then in the out-side of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Young Fetherstone will know him?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hee's gone into the towne, and will not returne this halfe houre.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Excellent if she would come.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay vpon my life sheele come: when she enters remember some of your young bloud, talke as some of your gallant commoners will, Dice and drinke: freely: do not call for Sack, least it betray the coldnesse of your man-hood, but fetch a caper now & then, to make the gold chinke in your pockets: I so.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Ha old Poet, lets once stand to it for the credit of Milke-streete. Is my wife acquainted with this.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: She's perfect, & will come out vpon her qu, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Good wenches infaith: fils some more Sack heare.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Gods pretious, do not call for Sack by any meanes.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Why then giue vs a whole Lordship for life in Rhenish, with the reuersion in Sugar,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: It were not amisse if we were dancing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Out vpon't, I shall neuer do it.

div.stage: Enter Greensheild disguised, with mistresse Greensheild.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p:
Out of mine nostrils tapster, thou smelst like Guild-hall two daies after Simon and Iude, of drinke most horribly, off with
thy maske sweete sinner of the North: these maskes are foiles to good faces, and to bad ones they are like new sattin out-sides to lousie linings.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: O by no meanes sir, your Merchant will not open a whole peece to his best costomer, hee that buies a woman, must take her as she fales: Ile vnmaske my hand heares the sample.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Goe to then, old Poet I haue tane her vp already as a pinnis bound for the straights, she knowes her burden yonder.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Lady you are welcome: you is the old Gentleman and obserue him, he's not one of your fat Citty chuffes: whose great belly argues that the felicity of his life consistes in capon, sack, and sincere honesty, but a leane spare bountiful gallant one that hath an old wife, and a young performance: whose reward is not the rate of a Captaine newly come out of the Low-coÅ«tries: or a Yorkeshiere Atturny in good contentious practice, some angel, no the proportion of your welthy Cittizen to his wench, is, her Chamber, her diet, her phisick, her apparell, her painting, her monkey, her pandar, her euery thing. Youle say your yong Gentleman, is your onely seruice that lies before you like a Calues head, with his braines some halfe yeard from him, but I assure you, they must not onely haue variety of foolery; but also of wenches: whereas your conscionable gray-beard of Farrington within, will keepe himselfe, to the ruines of one cast waighting-woman an age: & perhaps, when he's past all other good workes, to wipe out false waightes, and twenty ith hundred, marry herâ

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: O well bould Tom() we haue presedents, for't:

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But I haue a husband sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You haue, if the knaue thy husband bee rich, make him poore, that he may borrow mony of this Merchant, and be layd vp in the Counter, or Ludgate, so it shall bee conscience in you old Gentleman, when he hath seized all thy goods, to take the horne and maintaine thee.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: O well bould Tom() wee haue presedents for't.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Well if you be not a Nobleman, you are some great valiant Gentleman, by your bearth: and the fashion of your beard: and do but thus to make the Cittizen merry, because you owe him some money.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O you are a wag.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: You are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: He is tane, excellent, excellent, ther's one will make him merry: is it any imputation to helpe ones friend to a wench?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No more then at my Lords intreaty, to helpe my Lady to a pritty waighting woman: if he had giuen you a gelding, or the reuersion of some Monopoly, or a new sute of Sattin to haue done this, happily your Sattin would haue smelt of the Pander: but what's done freely, comes like a present to an old Lady, without any reward, and what is done without any rewarde, comes like wounds to a Souldier, very honourably not-withstanding.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: This is my breeding Gentlewoman: and whether trauaile you?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: To London sir, as the old tale goes, to seeke my fortune.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Shall I be your fortune Lady?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O pardon me sir, Ile haue some young landed heire to be my Fortune, for they fauour shee fooles more then Cittizens.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Are you married?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Yes, but my husband is in garrison ith' Low-countries, is his Colonels bawd, and his Captaines Iester: he sent me word ouer, that he will thriue: for though is apparell lie ith Lumbard, he keepes his conscience ith' Muster-booke.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Hee may do his countrie good seruice Lady.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I as many of your Captaines do, that fight as the Geese saued the Capitoll, onely with pratling: well, well, if I were in some Noblemans hands now, may be he would not take a thousand pounds for me.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: No sir: and yet may be at yeares end, would giue me a brace of hundreth pounds to marry me to his Bayly, or the Solicitor of his Law sutes: whos's this I beseech you?

div.stage: Enter mistrisse Maybery her haire loose, with the Hostice.

sp.speaker: Hostice.
sp.p: I pray you forsooth be patient.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Passion of my heart, Mistresse Maybery. Exeunt Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Now will shee put some notable trick, vpon her Cuckoldly husband.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Why how now Wife, what meanes this? ha?

sp.speaker: Mi. Me.
sp.p: Well, I am very well: Ã´ my vnfortunate parents, would you had buried me quick, when you linkt me to this misery.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O wife be patient, I haue more cause to raile wife.

sp.speaker: Misters May.
sp.p: You haue, proue it, proue it: wheres the Courtier, you should haue tane in my bosome: Ile spit my gall in's face, that can tax me of any dishonor: haue I lost the pleasure of mine eyes, the sweetes of my youth, the wishes of my bloud: and the portion of my friends, to be thus dishonord, to be reputed vild in London, whilst my husband prepares common diseases for me at Ware, O god O god.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: Prettily wel dissembled.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: As I am true hostice you are to blame sir, what are you maisters: Ile know what you are afore you depart maisters, dost thou leaue thy Chamber in an honest Inne, to come and inueagle my costomers, and you had sent for me vp, and kist me and vsde me like an hosticeâª twold neuer haue greiued mee, but to do it to a stranger.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Ile leaue you sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Stay, why how now sweete gentlewoman, cannot I come forth to breath my selfe, but I must bee haunted, raile vpon olde Bellamont, that he may discouer them, you remember Fetherstone Greensheild.

sp.speaker: Mist. May.
sp.p: I remember them, I, they are two as coging, dishonorable dambd forsworne beggerly gentlemen, as are in al London, and ther's a reuerent old gentleman to, your pander in my conscience.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Lady, I wil not as the old goddes were wont, sweare by the infernall Stix: but by all the mingled wine in the seller beneath, and the smoke of Tobacco that hath fumed ouer the vessailes, I did not procure your husband this banqueting dish of suckket looke you behold the parenthesis.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Nay Ile see your face too.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: My deare vnkind husband; I protest to thee I haue playd this knauish part only to be witty.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: That I might bee presently turned into a matter more sollid then horne, into Marble

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your husband gentlewoman: why hee neuer was a souldier

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I but a Lady got him prickt for a Captaine, I warrant you, he wil answere to the name of Captaine, though hee bee none: like a Lady that wil not think scorne to answere to the name of her first husband; though he weare a Sope-boyler.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Hange of thou diuill, away.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: No, no, you fled me tother day,
When I was with child you ran away,
But since I haue caught you now.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: A pox of your wit and your singing.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay looke you sir, she must sing because weele be merry, what though you rod not fiue mile forward, you haue found that fatall house at Brainford Northward, O hone ho no na ne ro.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: God refuse mee Gentlemen, you may laugh and bee merry: but I am a Cockold and I thinke you knew of it, who lay ith segges with you to night wild-ducke.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: No body with me, as I shall be saued: but Maister Fetherstone, came to meete me as far as Roistone.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Fetherstone.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: See the hawke that first stoopt, my phesant is kild by the Spaniell that first sprang all of our side wife.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Twas a pretty wit of you sir, to haue had him rod into Puckeridge with a horne before him; ha: wast not;

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Or where a Cittizen keepes his house, you know tis not as a Gentleman keepes his Chamber for debt, but as you sayd euen now very wisely, least his hornes should vsher him.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Very good Fetherstone he comes. Enter Fetherstone.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Luke Greeneshield Maister Maybery, old Poet: Mol and Kate, most hapily incounterd, vdslife how came you heather, by my life the man lookes pale.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: You are a villaine, and Ile mak't good vpon you, I am no seruingman, to feede vpon your reuersion.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Go to the ordinary then.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This is his ordinary fit & in this she is like a London ordinary: her best getting comes by the box.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: You are a dambd villaine.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: O by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: No, vdslife, Ile go instantly take a purse, be apprehended and hang'd for't, better then be a Cockold.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Best first make your confession sirra.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Tis this thou hast not vsed me like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: A Gentleman: thou a gentleman: thou art a Taylor.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ware peaching.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p:
No sirra if you will confesse ought, tell how thou hast
wronged that vertuous Gentlewoman: how thou laiest at her two yeare together to make her dishonest: how thou wouldest send me thether with letters, how duely thou woudst watch the cittizens wiues vacation, which is twice a day; namely the exchainge time, twelue at noone and six at night, and where she refused thy importunity, and vowed to tell her husband: thou wouldest fall downe vpon thy knees, and intreat her for the loue of Heauen, if not to ease thy violent affection, at least to conceale it, to which her pitty and simple vertue consented, how thou tookest her wedding ring from her, Met these two Gentlemen at Ware: fained a quarell, and the rest is apparant, this onely remaines what wrong the poore Gentlewoman hath since receaued by our intollerable lye; I am most hartely sorry for, and to thy bosome will maintaine all I haue said to bee honest.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Victorie wise thou art quit by proclamation.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sir you are an honest man, I haue knowne an arrant theefe for peaching made an officer, giue me your hand Sir.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O filthy abhominable husband did you all this?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Certainely he is no Captaine he blushes.

sp.speaker: Mi. May.
sp.p: Speake Sir did you euer know me answere your wishes.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: You are honest, very vertuously honest.

sp.speaker: Mi. May.
sp.p: I wil then no longer be a loose woman, I haue at my husbands pleasure tane vpon me this habit of iealousie: Ime sorry for you, vertue glories not in the spoyle but in the victory.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p:
How say you by that goody Sentence, looke you sir; you gallants visit cittizens houses, as the Spaniard first sailed to the Indies, you pretend bying of wares or selling of lands: but the end proues tis nothing but for discouery & conquest of their wiues for better maintenance why looke you, was he aware of those broken patience when you met him at Ware, & possest him of the downfal of his wife: you are a Cockcold you haue paÌderd your own wife to this gentleman better men haue don it, honest Tom(), wee haue presidents for't, hie you to London: what is more Catholick ith Citty then for husbands daily for to forgiue, the nightly sins of their bedfellowes: if you like not that course but to intend to be rid of her: rifle her at a Tauerne, where you may swallow
downe some fifty wisacres sonnes and heires to old tenements, and common gardens: like so many raw yeolkes with Muskadine to bed-ward.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: O filthy knaue, dost compare a woman of my cariadge to a horse.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And no disparagment; for a woman to haue a high forhead: a quick eare, a full eye, a wide nostrell, a sleeke skin, a straight back, a round hip, and so forth is most comely.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But is a great belly comly in a horse sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No Lady.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And what thinke you of it in a woman I pray you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Certainly, I am put downe at my owne weapon; I therefore recant the riflying? no there is a new trade come vp for cast Gentlewemen, of peeriwip making: let your wife set vp ith Strand, and yet I doubt, whither she may or no, for they say, the women haue got it to be a corporation; if you can you may make good vse of it, for you shall haue as good a comming in by haire (tho it be but a falling commodity) & by other foolish tyring, as any betweene Saint Clements and Charing.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Now you haue run your selfe out of breath, here me: I protest the gentlewoman is honest, and since I haue wrong'd her reputation in meeting her thus priuately, Ile maintaine her: wilt thou hang at my purse Kate, like a paire of barbary buttons, to open when tis full, and close when tis empty?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Ile be diuorc'd by this Christian element, and because thou thinkst thou art a Cockold, least I should make thee an infidell, in causing thee to beleeue an vntrueth, Ile make thee a Cockold.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Excellent wench.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Come, lets go sweete: the Nag I ride vpon beares double, weele to London.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Do not bite your thumbes sir.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Bite his thumbe!
Ile make him do a thing worse than this,
Come loue me where as I lay.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: What Kate!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: He shall father a child is none of his,
O the cleane contrary way.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: O lusty Rate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Me thought he sayd, euen now you were a Taylor.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: You shall heare more of that hereafter, Ile make Ware and him stinck ere he goes, if I bee a Taylor, the roagues naked weapon shall not fright me, Ile beate him and my wife both out ath Towne with a Taylors yard. Exit.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O Valiant sir Tristram; roome there.

div.stage: Enter Philip Leuer-poole and Chartly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Newes father, most strang newes out of the Low-countries, your good Lady and Mistris that set you to worke vpon a dozen of cheese-trenchers is new lighted at the next Inne, and the old venerable Gentlemans father with her.

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.p: Let the gates of our Inne be lockt vp, closer than a Noble-mans gates at dinner time.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Why sir, why?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: If shee enter here, the house wil be infected: the plague is not halfe so dangerous, as a Shee-hornet: Philip this is your shuffling a the cardes, to turne vp her for the bottom carde at Ware.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: No as Ime vertuous sir, aske the two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: No in troth sir; shee told vs, that inquiring at London for you or your sonne, your man chalkt out her way to Ware.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I wud Ware might choake 'em both, Maister Maybery, my horse and I will take our leaues of you? Ile to Bedlam agen rather than stay her.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Shall a woman make thee flie thy country? stay, stand to her tho shee were greater than Pope Ioane, what are thy braines coniuring for, my poeticall bay-leafe-eater?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: For a sprite a the buttry, that shall make vs all drinck with mirth if I can raize it: stay, the chicken is not fully hatcht, hit I beseech thee: So; come! wil you be secret Gentlemen and assisting.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: With browne bills if you thinke good.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What wil you say, if by some trick we put this little Hornet into Fetherstones bosome, and marry 'em togither.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Fuh, tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Most possible, Ile to my trencher-woman, let me alone for dealing with her: Fetherstone Gentlemen shalbe your patient.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: How! how?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thus: I will close with this country Pedlar mistrisse Dorothy (that trauels vp and downe to exchange Pinnes for Cunny-skins) very louingly, she shall eate of nothing but sweet-meates in my company (good words) whose taste when she likes, as I know shee will, then will I play vpon her with this Artillery, that a very proper man, and a great heyre (naming Fetherstone) spyed her from a window, when shee lighted at her Inne, is extreamly falne in loue with her, vowes to make her his wife, if it stand to her good liking, euen in Ware; but being (as most of your young Gentlemen are) some-what bashfull, and ashamde to venture vpon a woman.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Citty and suburbes can iustifie it: so sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hee sends mee (being an old friend) to vndermine for him: Ile so whet the wenches stomack, and make her so hungry, that she shall haue an appetite to him, feare it not; Greenesheild shall haue a hand in it too, and to bee reuengde of his partner, will I know strike with any weapon.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: But is Fetherstone of any meanes? els you vndoe him and her.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Hee has land betweene Foolham and London, he would haue made it ouer to me: to your charge Poet, giue you the assault vpon her, and send but Fetherstone to mee, Ile hang him by the gills.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hees not yet horst sure, Phillip, go thy wayes, giue fire to him, and send him hither with a powder presently.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hees blowne vp already. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Gentlemen youle stick to the deuise, & looke to your plot?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Most Poetically: away to your quarter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I marche, I will cast my rider gallants: I hope you see who shall pay for our voyage. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Phillip and Fetherstone.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: That must hee that comes here: Maister Fetherstone, O Maister Fetherstone, you may now make your fortunes weigh ten stone of Fethers more then euer they did: leape but into the Saddle now, that stands empty for you, you are made for euer.

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: An Asse Ile be sworne.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: How for Gods sake? how?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
I would you had, what I could wish you, I loue you, and
because you shall be sure to know where my loue dwels, looke you sir, it hangs out at this signe: you shall pray for Ware, when Ware is dead and rotten: looke you sir, there is as pretty a little Pinnas, struck saile hereby, and come in lately; shee's my kinse-woman, my fathers youngest Sister, a warde, her portion three thousand; her hopes if her Grannam dye without issue, better.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Her Gardian goes about to marry her to a Stone-cutter, and rather than sheele be subiect to such a fellow, sheele dye a martyr, will you haue all out? shee's runne away, is here at an Inne ith' towne, what parts so euer you haue plaid with mee, I see good parts in you, and if you now will catch times hayre that's put into your hand, you shall clap her vp presently.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Is she young? and a pretty wench?

sp.speaker: Leuer.
sp.p: Few Cittizens wiues are like her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Yong, why I warrant sixteene hath scarce gone ouer her.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Sfoot, where is she? if I like her personage, aswell as I like that which you say belongs to her personage, Ile stand thrumming of Caps no longer, but board your Pynnis whilst 'tis hotte.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Away then with these Gentlemen with a French gallop, and to her: Phillip here shall runne for a Priest, and dispatch you.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Will you gallants goe along: wee may be married in a Chamber for feare of hew and crie after her, and some of the company shall keepe the doore.

sp.speaker: May,
sp.p: Assure your soule shee will be followed: away therefore. Hees in the Curtian gulfe, and swallowed horse and man: hee will haue some body keepe the doore for him, sheele looke to that: I am yonger then I was two nights agoe, for this phisick.â how now?

div.stage: Enter Captaine. Allom. Hans, and others booted.

sp.speaker: Capt,
sp.p: God plesse you; is there not an arrant scuruy trab in your company, that is a Sentill-woman borne sir, and can tawg Weleh, and Dutch and any tongue in your head?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: How so? Drabs in my company: doe I looke like a Drab-driuer?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Trab will driue you (if she put you before her) into a pench hole.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Is not a Gentleman here one Maister Bellamont sir of your company.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Yes, yes, come you from London, heele be here presently.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Will he? tawsone, this oman, hunts at his taile like your little Goates in Wales follow their mother, wee haue warrants here from maister Sustice of this shire, to shew no pitty nor mercie to her, her name is Doll.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Why sir, what has she committed? I thinke such a creature is ith' towne.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What has she committed: ownds shee has committed more than man-slaughters, for shee has committed her selfe God plesse vs to euerlasting prison: lug you sir, shee is a punke, she shifts her louers (as Captaines and Welsh Gentlemen and such) as she does her Trenchers when she has well fed vpon't, and that there is left nothing but pale bones, shee calls for a cleane one, and scrapes away the first.

div.stage: Enter Bellamont, and Hornet, with Doll betweene them Greeneshield, Kate, Mayberies wife, Phillip, Leuerpoole, and Chartley.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Gods so Maister Fetherstone, what will you do? here's three come from London, to fetch away the Gentlewoman with a warrant.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: All the warrants in Europe shall not fetch her now, she's mine sure enough: what haue you to say to her? shee's my wife.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ow! Sbloud doe you come so farre to fishe and catch Frogs? your wife is a Tilt-boate, any man or oman may goe in her for money; shee's a Cunny-catcher: where is my mooueable goods cald a Coach, and my two wild peasts, pogs on you wud they had trawne you to the gallowes.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: I must borrow fiftie pound of you Mistris Bride.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yaw vro, and you make me de gheck, de groet foole, you heb mine gelt to: war is it?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Out you base scums, come you to disgrace mee in my wedding shooes?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Is this your three thousand pound ward, yee tolde mee sir she was your Kinswoman.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Right, one of mine Awnts.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who payes for the Northren voyage now lads?

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Why do you not ride before my Wife to London now? the Woodcocks ith' Sprindge.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O forgiue me deere husband! I will neuer loue a man that is worse than hangd, as he is.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Now a man may haue a course in your Parke?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Hee may sir.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Neuer I protest, I will bee as true to thee, as Ware and Wades-mill are one to another.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Well, it's but my fate: Gentlemen, this is my opinion, it's better to shoote in a Bow that has beene shot in before, and will neuer start, than to draw a faire new one, that for euery Arrow will bee warping: Come wench wee are ioynd, and all the Dogs in France shall not part vs: I haue some lands, those Ile turne into money, to pay you, and you, and any: Ile pay all that I can for thee, for Ime sure thou hast paid me.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: God giue you ioy.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Come lets be merry, lye you with your owne Wife, to be sure shee shall not walke in her sleepe: a noyse of Musitians Chamberlaine.

lg.l: This night lets banquet freely: come, weele dare,
Our wiues to combate ith' greate bed in Ware. Exeunt.
